novel_text:
She ran before the sun had decided what color to become. Bandung was a basin of mist, a bowl of half-breathed air, and she cut through it along the lane that still held night in its asphalt. On the backstretch, between the banana trees that leaned beyond the fence and the bleached sponsor banners, Dara could hear her own lungs and the soft thud of her shoes as if someone else were keeping time for her.

“Last set,” Pak Bram called. His voice had a rasp that made everything sound like a warning.

She didn’t answer. She kept her eyes level, refusing to look at the hurdles spread along lane three like sleeping dogs. The hurdles were for later. The warm-up called for circuits and acceleration. She took the curve and pressed into the straight, shoulders low and loose, jaw easy. The mist pulled away. The city in the distance, beyond the stadium wall, paled with the hint of morning traffic.

If she kept her eyes on the ground three meters ahead, she didn’t have to count, she didn’t have to measure her footfalls. She knew them by how her hips moved, how the left calf tightened at seventy meters, how the right shoulder dropped when her concentration broke and she remembered—no.

She cut that thought off like a finger pulled back before the flame. The brain is a liar. The body knows.

She finished the acceleration and walked back, hands on hips, heart shouting. A small thread of hair had come free from her ponytail. It tickled her cheek like a whisper.

“Why you look like someone’s chasing you?” The voice came from the fence. Vina had draped herself over the railing, her smile lazy and sharp. She was a sprinter, a snapped elastic band coiled in human shape. She saw things, then told them to the wrong people.

“I have a coach,” Dara said, keeping her breath even. “Do you?”

“Oh, I listen to him sometimes.” Vina winked toward the middle of the field where Pak Bram hunched as if he could will them all into speed by compressing his bulk into a boulder. “You know there’s a rumor you made him change the schedule.”

“I don’t hear rumors.”

“Everyone hears rumors.”

Dara pretended to tie her shoe. Traffic sighed beyond the stadium. A bird, one of the brown, ordinary ones that nested in the tunnel lights, skittered along the metal struts and dropped something unidentifiable onto the track's border.

The hurdles in lane three leaned with smug inevitability.

She took water from her bag, sipped, swallowed, and didn’t let herself look further into the bag where the tape was, the spikes, the little sachet that made her palms dry out as soon as she saw it. Among her socks, the sachet rattled like teeth.

“Langsung ya, Dara.” Pak Bram clapped. “Five sets. We go over, we go back. Pace is race. No cutting.”

There were some murmurs, someone groaned, someone else half-laughed. Dara set the bottle down. She jogged to the start of the lane, to the first hurdle, the metal paint flaking off a little where the adjustable legs had rubbed too often.

“Hey,” Naya whispered. Naya had a voice like rain. “You okay?”

“I’m fine,” Dara said.

They stood the hurdles. The metal legs squeaked. She could see the small rust-dark circles where rubber feet had been ripped off and replaced. Her lane looked like a sentence spelled out in obstacles, punctuation marks that only made sense when she ran.

“Siap?” Pak Bram’s whistle was in his mouth, his fingers around the stopwatch.

“Siap,” they said, a little chorus, the words rolling and making light of everything.

It wouldn’t be bad. Not now. There was nothing in the open. They always searched; they always—they? She laughed at herself, a tiny, mean laugh in the back of her throat. They, as if the spiders were a gang with a leader, a strategy. As if the one that had been her first wasn’t—no. Focus.

The first set, she lifted, drove the knee, counted her steps to the takeoff, the same rhythm she always had, the one she had drilled into the muscle between calf and shin, into the angle of her hip, into the hinge of her ankle. She cleared, she landed, the world contracted to a route and a breath. Nothing shifted in the periphery. No black or brown or anything flickering. She felt good, even ease. She turned at the end, slowed, walked back, tasted the metal in her mouth that comes when the morning is cold and your lungs are trying to make fire.

She could do this.

Second set, she clipped the third hurdle. The stumble made her vision bump for a second. She let the adrenaline go through her and out. When she landed, a movement bloomed at the edge of her left eye. Something on the next lane over, small, almost a dot, fast in that lurching way that made her whole body smell like it's already sweating.

It was nothing. A drop falling from the metal. A leaf. A—don’t think the word.

She cleared the fourth, the fifth. Her stride shortened; she overcompensated; she felt the trail leg catch and pulled it back with a grunt that Naya would hear later and ask about.

When she walked back after the set, the small movement was where her bag was, by the fence, on the concrete lip. She told herself she would not look. She told her brain no. She looked.

A spider, not big, not—maybe the size of a thumbprint if a thumbprint were a waiting thing. Brown, body a little low, legs quick and pointed the way stray nails point out from a beam. It was on the outside of her bag, near the zipper pull. A line of web that you could mistake for a hair had already touched the metal.

No. No no no. It was nothing. They were always somewhere. This was outside. But inside, in, inside where her socks were, where she had put her shoe, where her—she couldn’t stop the image of a narrow space into which any number of brown bodies could press. She felt the place below her rib tighten, the stomach’s fist.

She heard Vina from the other lane. “Dara? You slowing? Come on lah. This is just practice.”

She tried to unclench. She tried to breathe past the rust.

“Next two sets double pace,” Pak Bram shouted. “We need race speed. This is not a picnic.”

Dara moved to the start again. She didn’t look at the bag. She didn’t look anywhere except the hurdle top bar, white and scratched, the chip that looked like a small tooth mark, her mark that she had made weeks ago.

“Ready,” she whispered to the track, to the ground, to her legs whose memory was sometimes more reliable than her heart.

She went. Everything came up to meet her: the first one intimately familiar as a bedpost at night, her own hands on the sheets. The second a suggestion of risk that she took with the casual courage of a practiced risk-taker. She landed, two steps, three, takeoff, push, flick. Breath. The third came wrong. Something sunk its tiny hooks into her lungs. On the edge of the lane, at the foot of the fourth hurdle, a small blackish tangle had lodged in the ragged seam where track and grass met. It moved.

Her legs made their decision before she did. They curled, they refused. She brought up her foot early and the hurdle told her immediately that she was wrong with the sharp crack of shin on wood. She went down hard, palms, knees, the taste of something that belonged to last week’s rain and the rubber of thousands of soles.

“Dara!” Naya’s voice, close but not touching.

She rolled to her back to get her knees up, to make space in her chest. The sky above the stadium was a blue so pale it reminded her of hospital sheets.

“Hey,” Vina said, coming up with that smile that never held her own teeth with anything but contempt. “What’s this? Aduh. The champion is kissing the track.”

“I’m fine,” Dara said, breath choppy. She sat up. Her shin throbbed with the ache that says it will grow into a dark bad-looking bruise and be a story later. She could feel grit sticking to the blood.

“It was just a stumble,” Naya said. She offered a hand. Dara didn’t take it.

“Again,” said Pak Bram, and the word cut everything else.

She stood. The tangle at the fourth hurdle had resolved itself into nothing now, or into something that had been scuffed away. Her bag by the fence was only a bag. She went again. She did not fall. The next set she took with the blind loyalty of a dream. When she finished, she could already feel the punishing conversation that would follow. She took her bottle again and tried not to glance down into the mouth of it for anything that might have floated in.

“Stop,” said the coach finally, as if he had kept himself from saying it for years and now was paying himself back in one syllable. He stomped to them. “Dara.”

“Yes, Pak.”

“Come.” He walked away from the group toward the lane marker painted like an old scar.

She followed, wiping grit from her knees and smearing it wider until she stopped, embarrassed at her own hand, and let it alone.

“You have to deal with this.” He gestured without looking at the hurdles, at the track, at her face that probably still had one drop of blood near her lip. “This thing.”

“I know.”

“No, you don’t seem to know. You are the fastest on this team at 400 with barriers. You have a chance to go to Jakarta again next month and maybe further. You can’t do that if you stop because…” He searched for the word. “Because a small animal walks nearby. It’s embarrassing.”

She felt the skin on her chest tighten. “I didn’t stop because—”

“You did. I see it. You see it before your feet see the hurdle, and when you do, your hips go back like you’re an old man carrying a sack of rice. You are not an old man. You are my runner. Tahan. Hold.” He set two fingers against her sternum. It was not tender. “You have to hold.”

The stadium had more wind now. It found her sweat and made it feel like fish scales.

“I can hold,” she said, and her voice either broke or was broken by some small pressure.

He watched her for a long second. His face, which could harden into a concrete slab when he wanted the boys to stop laughing and get serious, softened in a way he probably didn’t know how to show. “You can. I know you can. But you have to choose to. Otherwise what am I doing here? You think I like waking up to watch you run into the ground like a cow? I want to be proud. I want to be proud and drink coffee at noon and say to my friends, ‘That one is my girl.’ So. Stop looking. Stop thinking. Hm?”

She nodded. “Yes, Pak.”

“Good. Now, clean your leg. We go again in twenty.” He left before she could nod again. He liked to leave on his own lines.

She stood there a moment and watched the air move the grass beyond the lanes in waves like a hand smoothing something that was not hair, not a shirt, something alive that needed to be calmed. When she bent to roll her sock down and see the shin, the blood had drawn a line like someone had tried to mark her for identification.

“You want my antiseptic?” Naya had come up quietly. She held a small bottle that looked like it had seen too much action in small bathrooms.

“Thanks,” Dara said. She took the bottle and the cotton. “You don’t have to—”

“Hush. If we let you bleed, Vina will brag she beat you because you fainted.” Naya smiled with only her eyes. She always saved the actual curve of her mouth for later.

They cleaned the scrape and taped it. The dull throb turned into a warmed coin spread under the skin. Dara could deal with that. Pain was easy. Pain was ancient.

“Is he right?” Naya asked finally, as if she had said hello after an entire day. “About why you stop?”

Dara laughed in a way that made no sound. “I see things sometimes.”

“You don’t like…?”

“I hate them.”

“Lots of people hate them. They’re not nice to look at.”

“I don’t hate the look. It’s the… the moving. The quick. The surprise. They don’t belong and then they do, suddenly, and the place becomes theirs. My head becomes theirs.” She kept quiet for a second, aware she had said too much. “It’s stupid.”

“It’s not stupid if you feel it.”

“It is stupid because I am not eight years old in a banana plantation. I am not—” She stopped. She had already said too much.

Naya nodded like she’d known where Dara’s sentence ended for a long time. “Sometimes the body keeps talking about things after we think the conversation is over.”

Dara handed back the bottle. “Kayak tukang bakso who keeps shouting even when he passes your street.”

“Exactly.” Naya laughed. The court beyond the fence had started to fill with futsal players whose jerseys didn’t match and who had more enthusiasm than any of them. “Eat something after. You go to hospital later?”

“Maybe.” The word tensed her tongue. “He has a new number.”

“The blood?” Naya kept her tone light, but her eyes, again, did the seeing. Everyone who has been to a hospital enough knows how many numbers there are and what they are worth.

“Yeah.”

“You want me to come?”

“No. Thank you.” She didn’t say she wanted to go alone because Rafi told better jokes when it was just the two of them, because he would mock the way she sat on the edge of the bed like a hawk ready to skewer anything, because he would ask for her earphones and pretend to hate her playlist and then ask for it again.

They went back to the track as the mist lifted fully and left the lanes like an unmade bed. Dara ran. She ran as if the stadium were the only place that would hold her, as if the city behind the wall would, at any moment, lift itself up and walk away. She ran until the muscles in her back sang in a flat tired voice. She went home by an angkot that smelled like fried noodles and cheap cologne. She sat by the window and let the city’s streets string themselves past: the toko roti her mother liked because the bread was always too sweet, the school gate where students hung in clusters like grapes, the billboard with a bright picture of a phone she couldn’t afford that told her she was behind, behind, behind.

At her house, her mother had left the window open to let the rain-smell out. The living room had a peeled leather sofa that had been new when her stepfather showed up with it after the wedding. He insisted that a sofa said things about a family. Dara had said nothing. She had not touched the sofa for two days after the delivery, which made her mother laugh and then cry. People have odd instincts about territory.

“Sudah pulang?” her mother called from the kitchen.

“Udah,” Dara said. “You made something?”

“Cilok. Your brother’s favorite. But he can only have a little. No pepper.”

Dara smiled, then shaped her face into something casual and not greedy. “I’ll wash first.”

“Jangan lama. The taxi to Rumkit Hasan will be here in half an hour.”

She went to the bathroom and washed her face, her hands, her legs. She stared at the purple bruises on her shin and thought of a map, a place you could only get to by making the wrong turn at least twice.

In her room, the wall held the medals that meant something and the medals that meant nothing but looked nice because they were round and shiny. A photograph of her father—her first father—stood on the desk in a cheap frame that had lost a corner. He had been a man whose wrists never sat easy; someone had always told him to do something else since he had been born. He had left when she was twelve and then one day had not been part of any more stories. Her mother had filled life with other things: a job at the laundry on Jalan Buah Batu, a stepfather with a motorcycle and an opinion on everything, a boy who was the stepfather’s and then was hers too. Sometimes you adopt each other without discussion.

She sat on the edge of her bed and, with a careful slowness that was neither superstition nor faith, reached into her shoe to check it was empty. She had learned to do this with the indifference of a person who had taught herself not to puke when she did. Her fingers found only the smooth insole and a little grit in the heel.

She took a breath that made the back of her throat buzz. She took a second one because the first had felt useful.

“Dara!” her mother called.

“I know!” Dara called back, and the sound spun off the walls.

The hospital had corridors that sounded the way sandals do on tile in the hours when errands have settled down. Every time wasn’t the first time, but every time was. She never got used to the grin of the sanitizer dispenser, the way it smacked the palm and made your hands smell like a hotel that promises you everything. She never got used to the way they ended up walking slower when they reached the ward. Practicing leisure for a place that has none.

Rafi sat cross-legged on the bed with the IV line barely moving and his hair trying to be hair again. His eyes had learned to be older and then had gone back to whatever age they wanted when he was with her.

“You’re late,” he said, with the kind of smile that made the nurses forgive him for everything.

“I brought music,” she said, ignoring the accusation because he enjoyed it. She set her bag down. “And news. And I’m sweaty so you’re lucky you can’t smell me through the mask.”

“Heh. You always smell like stadium soup.” He leaned back, exaggerated a swoon. “What news? Is the coach still a rock with a watch?”

“He is more of a watch with a rock attached.” She pulled a chair up to the bed, felt the leg catch on the edge of the rug someone had put to make the room not a room. “He told me to stop looking.”

“Good advice. Most things are uglier when you look.”

“You’re ugly when I look,” she said, and he laughed the way people laugh when they live inside a body that hurts often: carefully, but with real light.

“How many today?”

“Five sets. Then he yelled. Then I made him proud. A little.”

“You?”

“Eh.”

“Everything you do you do loud, even if you don’t speak. You don’t need a coach to yell for you.”

She wondered if he knew about the stop, about the aimless fear that had knocked into her like a small animal hitting your ankle when you’re trying to climb stairs. She wondered how much she let him see when she pretended not to. She didn’t want to be another thing that needed nurse eyes.

He took her hand and squinted at the bruises. “You fell.”

“Nothing. The hurdle and I had a misunderstanding.”

“You should see the other guy.”

“The other guy is metal.”

“My sister fought a machine and survived. Nice. Did you get video?”

“No.” She paused. “Why do you want everything in your head to be on a screen?”

“Because my head is weird sometimes.” He tapped his temple with one finger, making a small rhythm. The IV tape quivered. “The screen is like a window. You can decide when to look out.”

“That’s not how windows work.”

“In my house they do.”

She would have let the joke sit there, because she liked it when he played with light that way, but his mother—her stepmother—appeared at the door with a look that said she was gathering things. Her hair, once always a tight bun, had softened into a practical knot with strands that seemed to choose their own work.

“Kita doa dulu,” she said. “The doctor will come. After that, we will see the blood, and then we will see what we will do.” She looked like she wanted to perform calm for everyone and then sit in the bathroom and let her breath stall.

They prayed. Dara tried to make her thoughts small and clean. She was always bad at this part. Her brain wanted to run laps during prayer. Her brain wanted to test its own pace. She gave up and just said thanks in as many ways as she could think: for the bed not creaking under Rafi when he turned; for the nurse who had told him a ridiculous joke about cucumbers yesterday; for the morning that had moved forward without asking her to promise anything.

After the doctor came and said things about counts and numbers and how they were already, thankfully, creeping. He didn’t use the word miracle because you’re not allowed to in a coat, but there was something in his face that refused to be neutral. A little lift. “We’ll see how he does with this next cycle,” he said. “He’s strong.”

When he left, a nurse leaned in and took a reading. She made the professional face. When she turned, she made a small smile at Dara that was almost a private conspiratorial thing: I know you. You did good by showing up. The gesture was quick and vanished. Sometimes the humans do that at hospitals. They opt for kindness between tasks. People act like it is nothing. It saves lives in inches.

Rafi was quiet, his chin tucked, the way he got when he was about to say something he had rehearsed. “I saw a spider today,” he said softly, playful on the first syllable and then not.

She felt the blood pull down in the back of her throat. “Where?”

“On the window. On the outside. Not… It was like the smallest. The wind moved and it tried to stay. It was doing something impossible and refusing to admit it. It made me feel brave for… I don’t know why. You would have hated it.” He looked at her. They were not ones for direct looks; the family was made of people who preferred side glances and jokes. He looked at her and said it. “You’re not okay.”

“I fell,” she said again. “The hurdle had an opinion.”

“Hmm.”

“And then there was…” She couldn’t say the word. It caught like a laugh in the wrong part of the throat.

He squeezed her hand once. “You don’t have to run all the time.”

“I do, actually.”

“No. You want to.”

“Yes. And?”

“And that’s all. That’s enough often.”

She glanced at her mother at the other end of the room, neatly arranging the biscuits as if their order would encourage some organ to behave. Her stepfather was not there. He had taken an extra shift at the workshop. He did that when he didn’t know what to do with his hands; he took machines apart and then put them back together to prove something to himself.

“Can you… When you are on the track, can you imagine something else? Like the spider is—”

“No.” She laughed. It came out like paper tearing. “If I imagine anything, it comes. That’s how it works. That’s how it’s worked since—” She stopped. He waited. She obeyed herself. “Since I was a kid. I stuck my hand in a bunch of banana leaves and there was a nest. They scattered and then regrouped on my wrist like I was a new branch. You can have a whole army on you and it feels like you have invited them. After that, any time… It’s like they have the only subs that don’t sub out. You know what I mean?”

He squeezed the hand again. “I know what you mean. But. You are good at telling your body to do what you want. I’ve seen it. You tell it and it listens. Mine doesn’t do that most days. I tell it and it laughs.”

She was about to protest, to tell him he was unlucky and she was lucky and that the universe assigned uneven loads of unfairness like a teacher who got bored and handed out punishments to the wrong kids. He lifted a finger to his mouth, a shh, a warm one, not an admonition. “You’re allowed to be scared of what scares you,” he said. “Just don’t be bored by it. That’s when it bites.”

They watched a clip on her phone of a hurdler in Europe taking ten perfect strides between each obstacle, each footfall the same argument resolved each time with the same conclusion. “Look at her,” Rafi said. “She’s not the fastest. She’s the most honest.”

“What does that even mean?”

“It means she’s not lying to her own legs. She doesn’t ask them to forget that they are legs.”

“You should write these on the wall.”

“I do. In here.” He tapped his head again. “The nurses think I’m practicing for a drum circle.”

When she left that evening, the light had turned the building gold in a way that made everything feel like it had been paid for. She walked the corridor and caught herself thinking of a particular corner where she had once seen a spider squat like a punctuation mark. She did not look at the corner. She would not give it the courtesy. It could have the wall. It could not have her. She stepped outside into air that held all the exhaust of the day and all the fried promises of street food.

At home, her stepfather was on the sofa with the television flinging the news at him without asking for consent. He glanced at her and then back at the screen because daughters were not a type of news he knew how to report. “How,” he said, flat.

“Good,” she said. “Numbers good.”

He grunted. She wanted to hate him for making love sound like accounting, but he had cried once in the kitchen with his head in the sink and he had let her see it because he had had nowhere else to put the salt.

She ate cold rice and the cilok that she didn’t tell her mother was too chewy and then she went to her room and lay down and thought of everything she had to do tomorrow and everything she had to avoid doing tomorrow. Her mind drew a little map where the stadium was in the middle, and around it were circles she had to run to get to a gate that would not open unless, unless—what? She couldn’t explain her own head even to herself. She laughed again in the dark because the laugh made the dark less smug.

In the morning, she woke before the call to prayer, her body remembering an appointment that the world had not yet made. She went to the stadium. The lane felt like a friend who sometimes told you truths you didn’t want and sometimes just sat beside you. People were late because it was Wednesday and everything is slow on Wednesdays. She walked along the inside edge of the track and spotted a small, dead spider near the drain.

It lay on its back, like a fallen soldier that never learned to die in a way that didn’t look melodramatic. Part of her wanted to kick it into the water that had gathered there like a mirror for small things. She stood over it and felt the little jump of disgust that was almost a habit. She breathed in. She said the word in her head that she had refused to say. Spider. Laba-laba. She said it again and again until the word was just sound, until the sound lost meaning and it became a drumbeat. The beat had nothing to do with the animal. It was a syllable. People made syllables into gods and enemies all the time. She would not give this one that honor or that hatred.

“Morning,” said a voice. Vina. Always early when she could be seen. “What you doing? Praying to the insects?”

“It’s not an insect,” Dara said, softly enough for herself.

“Oh, excuse me, Wikipedia.”

“Good morning,” Naya said, appearing like a small honest secret, like someone you forgot you had promised yourself you would be. “Warm up?”

They ran in easy circles, the kind that made your knees remember a younger time when your body didn’t care that it was working; it thought play had just decided to grow a plan. The sky was mean and grey. The coach had not arrived yet. For ten minutes, they laughed at a dog that found a bit of tape and shook its head as if the tape were tapping back. For five minutes, they were alive in a way that made everything they had to do later feel like something that could be done.

When the coach arrived, he was already frowning. “We have a visitor,” he said, and they all stared at him. He pointed to the bleachers. A man in a soft jacket and neat shoes sat with his phone in his hand like it was a part of his blood. “Sponsor,” the coach said. “Maybe. If we don’t behave stupid.”

They lined up. They did what people do when new eyes arrive. They made their movement clean and crisp. Vina lifted off her block like a flame that had decided to pretend to be metal. Naya steered her breath like a conductor. Dara did not alter her stride as much as she wanted to because she knew the price of performance, because she could not afford the after cost.

On the third set of hurdles, during the return run, a small piece of paper fluttered across lane two and landed on her path. It shocked her with how her chest clenched. What became a spider, what becomes something else. A paper was not a body; it was as alive as a bucket. She planted, she lifted, she landed. The paper clung to her shoe for a second, then came off. The sponsor watched. The coach watched the sponsor. The morning watched them all like an indifferent old person who had seen better athletes, better deals, better excuses.

After, the sponsor clapped in a way that suggested he was made of compliments, not of bone. He told them about shoes and opportunity and social media. He told them about how running could be a platform. He looked at Dara and held the look half a second longer than he had held the others. This made Vina’s mouth do something too quick to be categorized. “We’re all about stories,” he said. “The city loves stories. You have a story, I think.” He said it the way a fishing boat captain might say, I know this bay has sharks.

“Everyone has a story,” Dara said, carefully tight.

“Yes,” he said, smiling. “But not everyone’s story is… visible.”

When he had left, the coach patted Dara on the shoulder in a gesture that belonged to fathers in films. “This is good,” he said. “Do not make it a bad thing.”

“I know,” she said, but some part of her was already making a list of everything that could go wrong if a stranger wanted to buy a piece of her life.

She went to the locker room after practice. It was concrete that had decided to be a room. The lockers had been painted a hopeful blue some years before. Now, the blue was a memory. There were shoes, a towel, a dead cricket near the drain. She opened her locker and reached for her bag and then pulled back, because when she had opened the zipper a month ago at the other stadium across town, a wolf spider had leaped out like a question you didn’t want to answer. It had landed on her shoulder, and she had made a sound none of them had ever heard her make. Vina had told the story three times in three different groups. By the end, the spider had been as big as a fist and had tried to take her medal.

“Just open it,” she whispered. Her own voice was trying to act like a coach. It didn’t even know where its whistle was.

She got the bag down to the bench and put it there. She put her palm flat against the rubber entire face of the thing and waited for the feeling in her hand to become normal. She pulled the zipper slowly. She saw fabric, shoes, a towel. A small hair caught in the teeth. No movement. She let herself look longer. She had to. She had to be able to see a thing for what it was for more than half a second or she would never outrun this. She would trip at a shadow and call it a predator.

Nothing. She took her towel and closed the bag and sat down and laughed in a real laugh that made one of the younger girls look at her as if she had said a marvelous lie.

When she walked out of the locker room, she nearly collided with Vina, who had been waiting in a pose like a magazine. “Interview,” Vina said, tapping her phone. “People asked who fell yesterday.”

“Did you tell them a meteor hit me?” Dara said.

“I told them you saw your ex.”

“I don’t have an ex.”

“Oh. Pity.” Vina put the phone away. “It’s all content, right?”

Dara resisted the urge to wipe her hands on her shorts. “I don’t have content. I have legs.”

“You have fear. People like that. They can be holy about it.” Vina tilted her head. “Tell me something, ya. You ever think that those of us who are not scared are bored?”

“You? You’re bored with your own shadow.”

“I love my shadow. It’s the only thing that keeps up.”

“Then why are you always behind in races?”

Vina laughed with genuine delight and the strange creature she turned into over the last ten meters of any hundred, where she could find teeth even on her elbows, disappeared, replaced by a girl whose father sold used tires and who had learned to make fun of herself before anyone else could. “You got me,” she said. “Hey. Come tonight. Cafe near Braga. There’s music. You need to be seen by people who are not wearing a stopwatch.”

Dara thought of the hospital, of Rafi’s eyes when he decided he would probably be alive at night and maybe wanted someone to tell him something he could not guess. “I can’t,” she said, and then softened it. “Next time.”

“You always say next time.”

“One time it will be true.”

“You have to make it true.” Vina flung a lazy salute and went, walking as if people were photographing her even while alone.

Dara took the angkot home. She ate with her mother and told her accountably cheerful lies and then she went to the hospital with a book she was never going to finish. Rafi was drowsy but not dreamy. He looked at her and then at the book and then at her again. “Read me what you think is good.”

She read until the page stopped pretending to be a page and became a river that ate the edges of the room. She read until he slept. She read after the sleep, quietly, because the words had turned into something that made the chairs less ugly. When she closed the book finally, she looked at the window. A small strand of web caught dawn’s rumor hour light. There was no spider. She said the word again, without hatred and without worship. She folded it into a breath. Then she put it away.

The next day, the sponsor called the coach. The coach told them they were going to have a meeting, maybe sign a thing. Vina wore lipstick under her mask and Dara wore the plain face that had taken her this far. They sat in an office that smelled like air conditioning and new carpet. The sponsor asked her about her story. She said she ran. He asked her why. She said because. He asked her if she had any challenges. She laughed and said she had a brother whose counts had decided to play games and a coach whose heart had decided to be rude by caring too much. He told her she spoke like a television. She hated that a bit. But she smiled. It was not the time to teach the room how to talk.

When she left, the coach touched her shoulder again. The touch had begun to become a habit. Habits are another way of agreeing with the world.

Later, she sat on her bed and stretched and winced when the bruise reminded her it had been promoted to full pain. She scrolled through her phone. There were messages. The big group chat choked on its own jokes. Someone had posted a video from yesterday—her stumble. Of course they had. The camera shook and the image was not humiliating so much as it was true. She was not a superhero. She was someone who could be wrong-footed by a small shadow. The comments had begun. They were many. Some were mean in the way people are mean when they are bored and want something to punch on their way to the bus. Some were supportive like a pillow that you put your face into and find too soft. Some said the word. Some wrote it like a threat. Some wrote it like a prayer.

She typed and then untyped a reply, a defense, a joke, a story. She put the phone down. She got up. She went to the kitchen where the tile was so old and white it had begun to decide to be yellow. She took an orange and decided to peel it like a person who had time. The peel came off in a spiral. She held it up like a little snake and then laughed at herself because she was being dramatic, because she always would be, because she was made that way before anyone had told her who she was supposed to be to make money from. She ate the sections one by one, the sting in her mouth like a new thought.

When she lay down, the city was not quiet, but it was not the kind of loud that broke you. It was the loud that tells you you’re part of a place and that place does not need you, and somehow that makes you feel safer because you can be there without earning it. She slept and dreamed that the hurdles were made of water and she had to run through them, not over them, and when she did, she came out on the other side wet but whole, and someone was clapping. Maybe the someone was her. Maybe it was a boy with tired eyes who laughed too loudly at cucumber jokes. Maybe it was the city, that old person again, clapping once, softly, for luck.Rain came in a fine sheet that made the red track look newly painted, and the stadium became a bowl of breath again, full of the sound of feet deciding what kind of day it would be. They did starts in the wet because most of the races that matter are run in weather that refuses to pick a side, and the way a foot meets slickness is part of a language you have to learn before you deserve to speak. Pak Bram told them they would have entries confirmed for Jakarta if the next two weeks didn’t betray them, and he said it in the same tone he used when he said don’t cut corners, the tone of an old promise he still believed in. “Waktu target bukan doa,” he said, and even though he tried to make it a joke, the stopwatch dangling from his neck swung like a pendulum that had been counting the same prayer since he was young. Vina ran with her shoulders daring the rain to get intimate; she said between sets that wet weather made the camera like her more and then laughed because she pretended not to care if the camera liked her, and Naya made a face and said, “Camera likes everyone who moves like they mean it,” and then glanced at Dara with that sideways honesty of hers that felt like a hand offered without announcement. Dara rolled a small stone beneath her shoe during a rest and told her calf to behave, and when the wind lifted a plastic bag past lane four like a ghost that had misinterpreted its own assignment, she let it be only a bag and refused to translate it into anything else. The brain is a liar, she told the rain in her head, and the body knows, and the body answered in the clean language of tendons sliding under skin.

The social media video had gone a little wider than anyone wanted; an aunt messaged her a sticker of a cat falling down stairs, a stranger told her she had to do yoga for her chakras, a boy from school she hadn’t spoken to since last year wrote to say he believed in her like he had free belief to give away, and the sponsor’s assistant had forwarded a link with a smiley face, which made her want to hit something soft. “You read comments?” Naya asked in a breath that tried to be casual and failed with dignity, and Dara said, “I scrolled until my finger remembered it had other work,” and Naya said, “Good,” and that was the conversation they could have when they were running and life was measured in meters. After the last set, while they were shaking their legs and trying to convince the day to be kind, the coach said there would be a meeting after, someone from the sponsor wanted images, “konten kreatif,” the words tasted like a syrup that had been in the cabinet too long, and he told them to be smart enough not to look stupid. “No drama,” he added, and Vina grinned and said she was born allergic to no drama, and he aimed a scolding at her that landed softly, because it was raining and even his bark had gotten wet.

The hospital let Rafi ride a wheelchair to the rooftop garden after lunch because his numbers had behaved like good students for three days, and the nurse winked like she was granting a criminal a night off. The garden was a rectangle of stubborn green standing up to a city that had tried for years to convince plants they were old news; the benches had flaking paint in cheerful colors that were trying not to apologize for their shabby sincerity. A woman in a cheap blazer was crying on the phone near the jasmine and didn’t notice anyone else, a child in a Spider-Man shirt kicked at nothing because nothing was the only thing that could take a kick without complaint, and a volunteer swept water from a corner and hummed a song from 1998 like she was still twenty. Rafi tilted his face to the grey and said he could taste the metal in the air and it was delicious because it tasted like outside, and Dara said she preferred her metal in hurdles and he said he preferred his metal in jokes. They watched a tiny bead of water find its way along a spider silk stretched between a railing and a leaf, and when it reached the dip, it paused because even water thinks before deciding some days, and then it dropped with a thrum so slight you had to want to hear it. “You okay?” he asked without turning, and she said, “I am tired of being interesting to myself,” and he laughed and winced and said, “Same,” and then he went quiet the way he did when pain was coming up the elevator to their floor. She talked through it later, telling him about a dog at the stadium that had decided to adopt a piece of tape and lead it around like a pet, and he told her about a nurse who had told him his eyebrows were reliable, and they both let silence have its turn, because you have to share silence in a family or it becomes an enemy.

The content team wanted an old warehouse near the river because brick photographs well, and they wanted morning light, and they wanted “authentic movement,” which made Dara want to show them a full practice and watch them try to keep up with the ugliness of a good session. The producer was a woman with glossy hair and a voice that would have sold rain to Bandung in November, and she said, “We love your energy,” after saying hello, which was a sentence that made no sense and made perfect sense. A young man who wore his headphones around his neck like a scarf had a mood board on his phone, and when he turned it toward Dara she saw a picture of an athlete bursting through paper that had been cut like a web, and across it someone had typed in a font that looked casual on purpose: Face Your Fears. She took a breath and felt her stomach tense the way a hand does when it sees a candle and wants to know if it will hurt. She said, “I won’t do webs,” and the producer blinked with surprise that was quickly covered with competence, and she smiled like flexibility was her birthright and said, “Of course, of course, we will pivot, we are storytellers, not… designers,” and then she turned to the young man and said in perfect polite Bahasa, “Ganti konsep ya,” and he nodded and scrolled like the future was a menu. Naya, who had agreed to come as moral support and also because free snacks were free snacks, stood just close enough that Dara could feel the agreement without words, and Pak Bram arrived late because he had made the mistake of believing a friend who said Jalan Sudirman would not be jam at nine in the morning, and he said, “No lompat-lompat yang bodoh,” as if that phrase could hold back the century.

They made her run across loose gravel while a drone made a sound like a dentist’s daydream and a photographer in a shirt with tiny cameras printed on it shouted directions that sounded like prayers. “Look at the horizon, think of something you want,” he said, and she thought of a thousand small square meals that arrived in the ward on time and warm; he said, “Can you give me determination,” and she wanted to ask what wattage that came in; he said, “Lower your jaw,” and she relaxed her mouth and thought about nothing because nothing is sometimes the only honest thing left. Vina arrived halfway through with clean lipstick and a speed that she put on like a jacket, and the room’s attention shifted the way it always does when someone enters with a relationship to light, and she played with the lens in a way that dared it to try to capture her whole. “You see,” the producer said to Dara between takes with the bright intimacy of temporary comrades, “everyone’s different, I want your quiet,” and Dara made a face she hoped read as grateful and not as the small animal sound she felt in the back of her throat. Someone set a coil of rope near the corner and someone else tripped over the coil and swore with the melodrama of youth, and Dara watched the coil, and for a second her brain announced that it had eight legs, and then she breathed and it became a coil again, and she moved her eyes, because you don’t have to challenge every shadow to a duel.

At home, the workshop smell had followed her stepfather like a second jacket, oil and heat and the old sadness of machines that will never be new again. He set a can of insect spray on the kitchen counter as if he were presenting a trophy to the house, and he said, “Kalau di kamar ada, semprot aja,” and she said, “I don’t want to make the room smell like murder,” and he grunted in a way that could be read three ways and she chose the kindest. He stood there, hands on the back of a chair like he was steadying a ship, and then he said in a voice that had not been sanded smooth by time with her yet, “Waktu kecil saya juga takut,” and when she looked at him with more face than she intended, he looked away like the wall had asked him a question, and he said he had fallen into a flood at Cicalengka when he was nine, and the water had been a living thing with things in it, leeches and plastic bags and a snake and a chair that had decided to float by, and for years after that he could not shower with the drain uncovered because the sound made his knees think the river had come back. “Sampai sekarang kadang masih,” he admitted with a little embarrassed laugh that had dust in it, and she said, “Okay,” because what else do you say to someone making a bridge he didn’t know how to finish, and he nodded and picked up the can and put it back in a cupboard because he had heard her, which was new currency in the house. Her mother came in with a bowl of tempe bacem like the smell would solve arguments, and she asked them if they had eaten, and they said yes even though they had not, because sometimes love starts with a lie that spares the cook for five minutes.

There were mornings when the stadium emptied of everything that wasn’t running, a spell where the birds took their meetings elsewhere and the futsal boys slept in and even the cleaners delayed, and on one of those mornings they did a time trial because you have to practice fear at the same pace as you will meet it. “You run the whole set like it owes you money,” Pak Bram said to the group, and he gave Dara a look that had the edges filed down, and she ran lane three the way you run when you suspect this version of yourself is the best one you’ll get today. The first two hurdles rose and fell like questions she had memorized answers to and not in a way that made her feel fraudulent; the third carried the shimmer of a remembered mistake and she refused it entry; the fourth was positioned where the old tangle had been and her lungs flickered, and she said the word in her head without glue, laba-laba, laba-laba, until it became percussion, and she kept her hips where he’d asked her to keep them, over the legs, not behind, and she landed with a sound that the track accepted. By the seventh, the world had narrowed to a corridor of breath and white bars and she felt the ache under her right shoulder that always arrived like a friend who needed a place to stay for the weekend and then cleaned up after themselves, and she smiled into the rain because even pain could be polite. When she stopped, her time was there on the coach’s screen and it wore a tiny grin that belonged to numbers that had decided to be generous, and he grunted in a way that meant he would brag later without making it a transcript. “Di ulang,” he said, because you never celebrate the first good attempt, and she nodded because ritual is part of technique.

After the second run, she walked with Naya along the grass because the lane can be jealous if you never leave it, and Naya told her about a cousin who had called to say she had seen the video and that fear wasn’t a good brand and that she should tell Dara to get over it. “Aneh orang,” Naya said, pushing a seed head with her shoe, “like she never cried when the electricity died and she thought ghosts wanted her Netflix,” and they laughed in the low way you laugh when you know laughter is one of the only therapies you can afford. Dara said she had an appointment at the hospital later because Rafi was due to change to a different regimen and everyone had to pretend to understand the math of it, and Naya squeezed her elbow, a small pressure that said she didn’t have to tell stories to keep company, the company would stay anyway. The futsal boys bustled in like a parade of misfitting jerseys and someone’s speaker played a song from summer, and the morning gave up its quiet with a shrug.

The sponsor’s representative messaged with angles and metrics and asked Dara if she would be comfortable telling “a little bit about your challenge,” and she typed, “I run the 400 hurdles,” and sent it, and the typing bubble froze and then revived and then the answer came back with three laughing emojis and a gentle pivot, and she didn’t give him anything else because not every truth was a bar of gold you chip off to pay a bill. Vina sent a selfie with the producer captioned “My new mom,” and a second later another message, “Kamu juga ya jangan jadi anak tiri,” and a little heart, and Dara didn’t know whether to be warmed or warned, so she let the message sit without an answer until it fermented into nothing. She stood at the sink and peeled an orange again because she had decided the fruit was a practice, and when the skin came off in two pieces instead of one she didn’t make it a metaphor, she just ate.

In the ward, Rafi had the look he got after the drip had been going long enough to make his jokes slower; he was still himself but the edges had been sanded and he was a little more tender to the touch without being sad about it. He asked her about the old warehouse shoot and she told him about the rope and the pivot and the drone that had tried to pretend to be a mosquito, and he asked if they’d paid her extra for the rain and she said, “They paid me attention,” and he said, “That’s a currency that depreciates,” and she threw a biscuit wrapper at him and he clutched his chest like a soap opera actor. Their mother—his mother—sat on the edge of the chair with her bag in her lap like the bag might get up and leave if not supervised, and she told them about a neighbor whose son had quit school to ride Gojek and who was now making more money than his father and how money didn’t choose sides, it just wore the shirt of whoever showed up first, and they listened because listening was free and made people stand up straighter. The doctor came and did his polite summary and left behind a diagram that tried to make blood polite too, and when the room was theirs again, Dara said, “Every time I think I’ve got it, my head plays me back a film I don’t want to watch,” and Rafi said, “Then we make a new film on top until the old one is hard to see,” and she said, “What are the scenes,” and he said, “First scene is you eating all my pudding,” and she said, “I can do method for that,” and their mother made a sound that came from a place before language and smoothed the sheet for the third time, and the machine beeped the way machines do when they are trying to be reassuring and failing but trying matters.

On a Thursday, the coach did a thing no one expected and asked a woman in a hijab and track pants with a posture that had not forgotten sprinting to come and watch them for an hour. He said her name was Bu Rara and that she had once run the two hundred until her hamstrings had decided to be dramatic, and now she worked with heads for a living; he said this like he was admitting to having a cousin in television. She watched them move and asked quiet questions that made it sound like she wanted to know what each of their shoes had to say, and she asked Dara between sets, “What do you do when the picture shows up,” and Dara said, “I tell my legs they are not a screen,” and she said, “Good, and then what,” and Dara said, “I breathe until the syllable becomes only a syllable,” and she nodded like that was a tool she would steal if she could and asked if she ever let the fear get bored, and Dara laughed and said that line belonged to her brother and she was just renting it. After, the coach hovered like a teacher trying to pretend not to hope for extra credit, and the woman told him they had good bones and dirty habits, and they could clean them, and he snorted because he does not believe in tidy minds, only in work, but he listened, which is a form of faith.

There was a day when the drain at the far corner failed and the track held a shallow lake with an ambition, and someone found a frog floating in an expression of resignation, and Vina squealed and jumped up on the bleacher like the frog had a grudge, and Naya coaxed it toward the grass with a shoe like she was negotiating with a bureaucrat. Dara watched from a distance where the frog could be a frog, and then a breeze unrolled a web between two posts like a tiny flag at half-mast, and there, at the center, a spider no larger than the head of a pencil sat in an attitude of ownership, and she felt the old electricity climb her spine like a song you cannot stop hearing because you were fourteen when you heard it on a bus. She did not walk toward it because courage does not always look like proximity, but she did not re-route her warm-up either; she let it be the corner’s corner, and she ran her arcs and her steps and her drills with the exactness of a person filing away one day that will not be the day she breaks, and when a lace came loose she did not make it a message. Later, while packing her bag, she stuck her hand into a shoe without making a ceremony of it, and when her fingers found only the insole and the grit and not a small panic with legs, she smiled with her whole face because you should let yourself have your own victories.

The message confirming her lane assignment for Jakarta arrived with the tone her phone used for announcements that mattered, the one she had chosen in a moment of melodrama when she wanted her life to have trumpets. She stared at the text as if it were a person in the room and said out loud to no one, “Lane five,” and then she said, “Okay,” with a long inhale that made the door to her room look like it had thought about being a finishing line. She thought of the stadium in Jakarta, of the way the sound there came off the seats like a slap, of the heat that came up off the track and made your calf talk to your patience, and she thought of Rafi’s eyes when she would call and he would say, “How many steps,” because he liked the math more than the result, and she thought of the sponsor’s clean office and the old warehouse and the rope and the refusal and felt her mouth pull into something that was not quite a smile because the smile would come later.

Night collected around the neighborhood with its usual untidy efficiency; a motorbike coughed and somebody’s grandmother shouted for a child who had learned to answer at volume only when paid in fried things, and the cat that kept pretending their roof was a river crossed above with a confidence that insulted gravity. Dara lay on her bed not sleeping yet, hands behind her head like a cliché she forgave herself for, and she traced the journey from the start to the tenth hurdle in the dark as if it were a prayer that didn’t mind being touched. She remembered the banana leaves and the nest like a rumor with legs, and how her father had laughed when she told him before he left laughing altogether, and she felt the old shame tug at the hem of her breath, the shame of being taken by surprise and making a sound that betrayed you, and she said out loud to the ceiling, “I forgive the sound,” and the ceiling said nothing because it was a ceiling, and she left the room for a glass of water and on the way past the living room her stepfather coughed into a fist and said without looking up, “Bawa jas hujan ya nanti,” as if rain were always possible, and she said, “I will,” and meant it like a promise to the city.

On Friday, the producer called to say the sponsor wanted to do a live stream after practice next week and that there would be questions from followers, some of whom would be children, which could be the cruelest audience in the world, and Dara said, “No spiders,” and the producer laughed and said, “We are a brand, not a zoo,” and Dara said, “I like zoos; animals are honest,” and the producer made a sound like a spoon on a glass and promised a set that would be nothing but lines and light. The coach, when told, rubbed his forehead as if that could refund minutes, and then said fine, but no extra running for a camera and no missing stretches for a camera, and he passed on a message from an old friend of his in Jakarta, a man who had once run the 800 like it owed him a house and who now sold rice cookers, and the message was, “Don’t give them your soft underbelly for free,” and Dara wrote it on a scrap of paper because sometimes old men see the same wolves.

That afternoon, the sky finally cracked and gave them real rain, fat and hard and bored of being polite, and the city smelled new and rotten at the same time, and in that honest wet, the drains did their song and the track thickened and everywhere small things looked for higher ground. Dara walked the perimeter in a poncho that made her look like a conscience and watched workers prop open a door with a brick and a broom, and she stepped around a flow of water carrying leaves like tiny boats, and when a small spider, displaced and furious in the way only tiny kings can be, pinwheeled out of a drain and tried to make a claim on a patch of dry concrete, she felt her pulse go dramatic and then slow, because there was nowhere for it to go otherwise, and she said the word in her mouth quietly once for her and once for the animal, and then she kept walking because staying is sometimes an agreement you can’t afford. When she reached the bleachers, Naya was there with a towel over her head like a monk and a grin she couldn’t hide, and she said, “You’re outside,” and Dara said, “Everyone’s outside,” and Naya said, “Yes, but you, now,” and it took Dara a breath to hear the meaning.

The coach gave them a rest day before the travel, which meant, in practice, that he told them to do the work at home where he couldn’t see it, and she did, because being unsupervised is not the same as being free. She texted Rafi that she would stop by after picking up a singlet, and he replied with a sticker of a dinosaur nodding like approval, and she sat on the angkot watching a man with too many boxes pretend physics were a rumor, and she thought about the moment of the gun, how it is a tiny explosion that pretends to be official, and the four steps to the first hurdle, and the way the last two always belong to an argument between fatigue and form. She could hear the city rehearsing its part in her head, the cheer that belongs to strangers who love the idea of running more than the runner, and she decided not to resent them for that; she needed ideas too.

On the ward, a new patient had arrived, a teenager with hair bleached a color that did not exist in forests, and he had a group of friends who made too large a noise in a way that was a protest against the quiet, and Rafi watched them with the mixed expression he gave any gathering: a little envy, a little tenderness, a little anthropological interest. Dara told him about lane five and the weather forecast and the rumor that an athlete from Surabaya had gotten a new coach with a reputation for cruelty disguised as excellence, and he said, “Don’t give the rumor your breath,” and she said, “I’m not,” and he said, “Good,” and then he dozed in the way that made his hand heavy in hers, and she read the same paragraph three times before realizing the book wasn’t the point, the chair was. Their mother came back from the canteen with a bag of crackers like she had conquered something and said she had run into a nurse who used to train for volleyball and who had said that pain on court was education and pain off court was a teacher with a stick, and they smiled because they liked it when the world kept bringing them metaphors as if language could be interest paid on suffering.

She left before the rain returned and walked past the corner where she had once refused to look, and she looked because she could, and there was nothing, and that was a kind of blessing, absence as mercy. At home, she packed with a discipline that had become habit, tape and spikes and snacks and the ridiculous little sachet that dried her hands because sometimes performance needed small cheats, and she put her shoe in the bag after checking it twice without flinching because practice had made that part unremarkable. Her stepfather knocked on the open door with all the awkwardness in the world and said, “Hati-hati,” and then added, “Bangga,” and then coughed because the word had surprised him, and she nodded with more face than she meant and said, “Makasih,” and her mother called from the kitchen that she had put fried rice in a container with a note because of course she had, and Dara said, “You put notes now,” and her mother said, “I put notes when I’m scared,” and Dara said, “You’re scared,” and her mother said, “I’m always scared,” and they both laughed like a secret had been polite enough to introduce itself.

The bus pulled out of the terminal too late and too fast, the way all departures in the country do when optimism meets schedule, and she sat by the window with the glass at her shoulder cool and a thin film of dust that would become a story on her jacket. Ahead, the road unspooled its familiar promises, curves she’d taken with classmates on school trips and with teammates whose names she no longer said out loud because they liked other sports now, and the driver’s playlist did a tour of heartbreaks and victories that made the aisle a dance floor in someone else’s imagination. Vina slept in a posture of total ownership and drooled without shame, and Naya watched trees the way a person collects green for later, and the coach pretended to be irritated by everything and secretly counted how many of them laughed without worrying about time. Dara pressed her palm flat to the window when the bus passed a stretch of fields where banana plants stood with their leaves bruised by last month’s wind, and she felt the old story try to sit in the seat beside her, and she said, not out loud, not a spell, just a sentence: “You can ride, but you don’t get to drive,” and the story made itself smaller because she had not, this time, offered it snacks.

They crossed into a city that always pretends it is the center of the map and forgives you for believing it, and the stadium rose like a machine that had been built to hold breath, and her chest tightened in the good way because some places give you permission without asking for your credentials. In the hotel room that smelled like a thousand previous nerves, she and Naya unpacked with the ritual of a new camp: shoes under the chair, tape on the table, spare socks in the drawer because they would forget them otherwise, and snacks in the top of the cupboard because Vina would steal them if they were visible. The coach knocked and barked at them to be downstairs in ten, and they were, and he took them to see the track because you should not meet the lanes only when you are dressed to impress them; you should say hello in your ordinary clothes, in your traveling skin, so the track knows you don’t want anything but mercy. The lines were whiter than home and the bars looked like they had been carved from official wood, and the wind said nothing because wind here is careful with strangers, and Dara walked lane five in flats and counted strides between empty hurdles and said the count under her breath like a psalm.

That night, in a bed that had seen every version of sleep, she lay awake longer than she liked and refused to name any of what her heart was doing, and finally she slept, and in the morning she woke before the call to prayer again because her body respects its own clock more than any bell, and she sat on the edge of the bed and tied and untied a lace while the city began its noise, and she thought of the dead spider by the drain, of the live one on a web that had survived a rooftop gust, of the rope coil at the warehouse and the boys with the drone, of her stepfather and the flood and the drain and his quiet confession, of her mother’s note on the fried rice that she had eaten in the bus and the way the taste had been a childhood she hadn’t noticed in years. She thought of Rafi counting her steps from a screen that would be too bright, and she thought of how he had said honesty like it was a metric, and she stood and did the things you do to make morning less wild: stretch, drink, wash, quiet your head, listen to your feet. When she met the team in the hallway, Vina bumped her shoulder with exactly the right amount of force and said, “Ready to be famous,” and Dara said, “Ready to run,” and Naya said, “Ready to breathe,” and they laughed because they were all telling the truth.The morning in Jakarta perspired before the sun did. Warmth climbed up from the track as if the surface remembered all the legs that had argued upon it and wanted to whisper their sentences back at the new ones. The stadium breathed in a different rhythm from home, wider, louder, a throat that could swell in an instant. The warm-up track was a world adjacent to the world, a ring of work that smelled like rubber and old chalk and the particular sweetness of isotonic drinks that promise mercy. The call room had its own weather: a hush with corners. When they stepped in, a volunteer in a neat polo shirt and a lanyard that dimpled his chest said numbers out loud like they were names and pointed to chairs like they were assignments.

Dara pinned her bib with the practiced fingers of someone who has stabbed herself enough times to have earned care. Lane five, heat two. She rolled the edge of her hamstring against the stretch of a trigger ball and tried not to think of it as a lottery. The other women were versions of her and not her: a girl from Makassar with hair tight as wire and a face like a decision, a tall woman from Semarang with an expression that had eaten nerves and decided they were calories, a Jakarta athlete whose eyeliner was perfect and who would refuse to let sweat claim it. They all made little bargains with their shoes and their laces, with their shoulders, with the ghosts that had booked seats in their lungs. Vina popped in and popped out like a firecracker because her call time was later and she didn’t know how to be anywhere for long without turning the place into a stage. Naya sat for a minute, quiet, a palm pressed into the back of Dara’s shoulder until her hand warmed what lay under skin, and then she went to her own lane where the watch would try to measure something it didn’t deserve to judge.

“Fifteen to start,” Pak Bram said softly, not looking at her because he didn’t like to give the room the satisfaction of seeing him care. “If wind turns and you feel the one, decide early. No improvisasi on seven. Keep hips.” He didn’t say fear, didn’t say picture, didn’t say syllabus of phobia or ancient field report from a banana plant. He tapped twice on the top of her quad with two knuckles like someone testing fruit at a market and walked away as if he had delivered a package and had two more doors to visit before nine.

They sent them out in a small procession that tried not to look like a parade. The stadium widened and the sound, that animal that lives in concrete and plastic seats, lifted its head lazily. Dara stepped into the lane and let her eyes rest where they were meant to be: on the white lines, the takeoff marks, the quiet bar on top of the first hurdle that would be the first promise she would make and keep. The bruise on her shin had matured into a color that you could wear to a wedding if you didn’t want compliments; tape held it like a considerate hand. She bounced twice, not for show, for the small interior calibration that made her ankles speak to her knees in a language no one else needed.

On your marks was not a sentence in this place. It was a ritual that asked you to believe in the flatness under your toes and the straightness of your intent. She set her blocks, felt the grippiness of the surface against palms, the cold of the pedals against spikes, the way her breath lit a small fire at the back of her throat. Set was a held photograph. The gun did not sound like a gun; it sounded like the moment lifting its face.

The first four steps were counted and not counted, done and forgotten as they needed to be. Hurdle one came and went like an old friend who doesn’t require greeting. Fifteen between. Two, breath and teeth soft, the ground rising and falling on schedule. Three was positioned under a piece of shade thrown by the big screen itself, and for a half of a step her brain wanted to assign meaning to the darker, wanted to film a movement that was not there, and she answered with the drum of syllable she had practiced until it meant nothing but meter—laba-laba-laba—until the mouth told the eyes to relax, and the eyes obeyed because the body likes to win an argument that feels honest. Four, she held; five, she made peace early with the switch to sixteen because the headwind had made the space between the bars feel a breath longer, and that decision saved the pattern from becoming a story in which she was the wrong character. On the backstretch, the noise settled into a hum so steady it could hold a person up. At seven, her right shoulder whispered its old complaint and she told it that she had rented the pain for the day and it could have it back tomorrow. Eight, nine, the body started itemizing debts, and ten arrived like a door you already had the key for, and then she was across and the line underfoot said nothing because the line never speaks to anyone; it simply is the definition.

She didn’t win the heat. The Semarang runner did, with a tiny lift near nine that looked like she had banked a surprise. Dara’s eyes flicked to the clock because everyone pretends they won’t and then does. The number stared back and it wore the face of a personal best by a whisker that would need a microscope, the kind of margin you could argue with if you liked losing arguments. She exhaled a sound that the microphones would probably not pick up and walked on her toes to let the acid drain where it would not complain as loudly. The sweat on her lip tasted like a welding of salt and relief. The board said her name in block letters that felt like seeing your own handwriting on a wall, familiar and strange, and the small heart she had been carrying in her mouth slid back down to where it belonged.

In the mix zone, where strangers with microphones smile with their teeth and with their eyes and with their phones, the sponsor’s assistant steered two cameras away with the diplomacy of someone who knew how to protect a story long enough to sell it properly later. “Recovery dulu, ya,” she said in a voice that would have calmed a roomful of cats. A boy with a student press badge and a shirt that wanted to be a dress shirt asked if fear was something you could train like quads, and Dara laughed in a full sentence and told him she preferred to train her hamstrings and mind and that fear was like rain: you learned to run in it or you went inside, but it wasn’t a muscle and it wasn’t a friend, it was weather. The boy nodded like he had been handed a phrase he would quote to someone attractive later and she felt a little bad for him because life would give him better quotes if he waited.

Back under the stands, the cool air licked at the sweat on her neck with hotel enthusiasm. Pak Bram met her with a face that had both a frown and a bitten smile hidden behind it and said, “Bagus. Jangan percaya bagus,” because he hated the way good tries to make people sleep. He tapped the screen of his phone where the splits lived and made a small face when it told him what he already knew, that she had given up a slice at six for a salvation at eight, and then he nodded because trade-offs are sometimes wisdom. Naya came in a few minutes later with that half-smile she reserved for when she had been brave without receiving any medals for it. Vina sent eleven messages in three minutes in the team group chat that was a chaos garden: a picture of her spikes next to a complementary banana, a selfie with a volunteer who looked like they were reconsidering volunteering, a video of a puddle trying to be a lake, a joke about lane draws, a sentence that began with “Manifesting—” and a disappearing sticker. Dara drank and let the cold sit in her stomach like a gecko that would flee if she startled it, and then stood so that her quads wouldn’t turn into furniture.

At the hospital, a nurse had arranged two juice boxes in a way that made them look like a polite sculpture, and Rafi watched her via a stream that had the gall to freeze every time a face looked good. He had texted the count he guessed before the race and he had missed it by one step and felt proud of being wrong because it meant she had adjusted before he had, and he loved her most when she changed the math and it still added up. He sent three claps and a gif of an old man dancing and the words “honesty metric going up” and she wrote back a picture of the clock with his name drawn on it in a way only siblings would find funny. Their mother had learned how to check live results with a frown like she was trying to make numbers behave with scolding, and when the page rejected her three times she scolded the page, and Rafi told her to let the page calm down because the whole city was pressing on it and the city did not know how to take turns. He felt a warmth under his tongue that he liked to pretend meant hope but the nurse would say meant the steroid at four p.m., and he kept his eyes on the small screen that showed his sister continue to be the kind of human whose body could be convinced of things.

In the afternoon, Dara sat on the hotel carpet and counted breaths while rain threatened the window in a way that turned the city into a person who promised to show up at seven and then arrived at eight with a story. She filled the time with care: flush calves, take shoes out of bag so they could remember their shape, call home and tell her mother the room was clean and the bed was comfortable and the breakfast had fruit because those were the things her mother wanted to know, part protocol and part prayer. Her stepfather, who rarely took phones into his hand the way a man who has broken his fingers on engines doesn’t take kittens casually, asked, “Suasana?” and she said, “Rame,” and he grunted like he approved of a full room. He did not say the word bangga this time, and she did not ask for it; sometimes a word’s previous appearance is enough to earn it a day off.

The final came sooner than her nerves preferred and later than her legs wanted. The sun is a kind of coach in Jakarta; it asks for loyalty and then punishes it. They taped and warmed and did the drills that are a language, A-skips and B-skips in a grammar you do not speak until your shoes know it. The call room’s air conditioner was a tyrant and a mercy and the chairs were arranged to encourage a particular kind of silence. A volunteer with a face that could have stopped a fire by speaking politely checked spikes and asked them to sign something that meant they were present. The Semarang runner looked like she belonged in any room she entered. The Makassar girl laughed at nothing in particular to show her throat that it was allowed to stay open. The Jakarta athlete examined the corner of her nail and then shook out her arms as if the track had to be told that those arms were coming.

On the way out, in that narrow corridor where sound changes shape, a small lint of something floated down from the lighting rig with the laziness of dust that believes itself to be interesting. It caught the edge of Dara’s cheek and then stuck on the curve of her jaw, and for a fraction her skin crawled the old crawl, the alarm that the body has so perfected, and she put her hand up with movement that pretended to be a scratch and wiped it away as if there had never been any contact. She did not look up to see if there was anything to blame, because blame is a hobby and she was trying to give up hobbies. She walked and the corridor opened and the field opened and the lanes were white lies she was ready to believe.

The gun spoke the way it always does when the moment doesn’t want to argue. The first hurdle asked only what she had already answered. The fifth, under an angle of light that made the bar look more present than it was, demanded a very small fierceness and got it. She kept fifteen because the wind had made a different promise today and her hips obeyed the course. Her arms remembered to be quiet and her face remembered to stay uninteresting. Somewhere a woman screamed a name that was not hers and somewhere else a child, convinced of his own heroism, took off on a sprint that would end in giggles before the stairs. At eight, the old dip at the shoulder visited and she didn’t tell it go away; she told it hold on and go with us, because some companions are easier to keep than to fight. Nine is a place where a person can become an animal with a plan; she let her legs do the remembering they wanted to do and kept her eyes honest, not looking at the tungsten bright finish but at the place where her foot would meet the next thing. Ten was a bar like a sentence she had written a thousand times and still meant. The last forty brings an honesty you cannot buy; she found the lean without borrowing from her neck and then the line came and the line went and the lungs turned themselves inside out in a practice that would never become normal.

She did not win the final either. The Semarang woman took it in the last ten with a lean that was a whole personality trait. Dara came second, closer than she would have guessed on a night when the stadium had measured her breath like a coin it could spend. The clock was pleased with her and said so; this time there was no microscope needed. It was there, a number she wanted to write somewhere secret. She walked because walking is what you do when you have asked your blood to carry fire and it is trying to negotiate for water. She put her hands on her hips because that position had helped her breathe since she was ten and had run the length of a paddy bund to beat a storm home. She looked for the camera with Rafi on the other side of it without moving her head, the way people look for birds they don’t want to spook, and she could not see him, but she could feel him telling some nurse that she kept her hips, that she had not let the picture take the lane, that she had not let weather pretend to be fate.

In the mix zone, the microphones had found larger prey and she was given the luxury of walking with only a small pack of curiosity at her heels. The sponsor appeared with the glare of a person whose shoes had not touched anything uncarpeted, his smile set to polite. He said congratulations like someone offering a napkin. He asked if she wanted to say a few words to the brand’s followers, and she said a few words to the people who buy shoes with their hope and their fear, and she tried to make the words plain because plain tastes better after a race. “I ran,” she said. “I tried to be honest.” The producer, who had grown a small weather antenna that could sense when a thing was enough, cut it there, and thanked her, and told her to sit down and breathe like it was a new skill they had invented together.

Vina arrived out of the stream with a time that didn’t owe anyone an apology, buzzing because that’s what she does and also because she had caffeine shaped like candy, and she kissed Dara’s forehead in a moment of theatrical tenderness that contained real salt. “Second is dangerous,” she said. “It makes you want more.” Naya came and leaned against a wall with the grace of someone who could make rest into a strong pose and said, “You were good,” and because it was Naya, it sounded like a sentence that carried six meanings.
