She looked for the camera with Rafi on the other side of it without moving her head, the way people look for birds they don’t want to spook, and she could not see him, but she could feel him telling some nurse that she kept her hips, that she had not let the picture take the lane, that she had not let weather pretend to be fate.

In the mix zone, the microphones had found larger prey and she was given the luxury of walking with only a small pack of curiosity at her heels. The sponsor appeared with the glare of a person whose shoes had not touched anything uncarpeted, his smile set to polite. He said congratulations like someone offering a napkin. He asked if she wanted to say a few words to the brand’s followers, and she said a few words to the people who buy shoes with their hope and their fear, and she tried to make the words plain because plain tastes better after a race. “I ran,” she said. “I tried to be honest.” The producer, who had grown a small weather antenna that could sense when a thing was enough, cut it there, and thanked her, and told her to sit down and breathe like it was a new skill they had invented together.

Vina arrived out of the stream with a time that didn’t owe anyone an apology, buzzing because that’s what she does and also because she had caffeine shaped like candy, and she kissed Dara’s forehead in a moment of theatrical tenderness that contained real salt. “Second is dangerous,” she said. “It makes you want more.” Naya came and leaned against a wall with the grace of someone who could make rest into a strong pose and said, “You were good,” and because it was Naya, it sounded like a sentence that carried six meanings. Pak Bram took his time coming over, not because he was withholding but because he liked to give the sound a chance to understand what it had just heard, and when he reached her he did nothing unusual, did not do a film gesture, did not raise a finger like a prophet; he just pressed his palm to the back of her head once, very briefly, like he had known her since she was shorter than a hurdle, and he said, “Lain kali,” and it was not disappointment, it was appetite.

The night was a different animal entirely outside the stadium. The city steamed and flashed and forgot easily and was proud of that. In the hotel room, the girls made a mess they would clean later and shared food that tasted better because it had been paid for by someone else’s money, a plum sweetness of victory without triumph. They watched replay clips that had already started making their rounds, captioned and filtered and slowed, and they made their own commentary, mean and kind in equal parts, and they were everything a team is that doesn’t need to hold hands to hold a line. Dara sent Rafi a picture of her shoes with their salt maps like coastlines and he sent back a photo of his whiteboard where he had written “15/15/16/16/16/16/16/16/16/17?” and then drawn a smiley face with eyebrows the nurse had complimented, and under it he had written, “not a guess, an autobiography.” She laughed out loud and then threw a towel at Vina for making a comment about celebrities, and then let herself fall quiet because quiet after a race is a feast.

In the morning, they had the kind of travel day that makes the body feel like an object moved by other people’s schedules. The bus smelled like sweat remembered and the road insisted on being itself with a stubbornness that made conversation part stop-and-go. The coach slept with his mouth open and an expression that would become myth if someone took a picture; they did not, because they all wanted to keep their coach human. Naya leaned her head on the window and drew a finger on the glass and left nothing. Vina made videos that would later look like more fun than they were, because that’s how survival edits itself. Dara watched the green smear of trees and the scramble of vendors at a toll gate and the way the sky above the edge of the city seemed to be considering a new arrangement and thought of all the ways the day had been almost a trap and then wasn’t.

Back in Bandung, the stadium looked shy after Jakarta, but it was the kind of shyness that comes with kindness built in. The next week was already arranging itself: a little celebration disguised as a jog, the live thing the sponsor wanted that they pretended was about community and was actually about inventory, the repeated question from reporters who arrive late and ask if fear is like a muscle and if she has advice for young athletes, the hospital visits that braid themselves between training like a constant friend, the house where the couch kept its arguments and the kitchen kept its peace, the dog at the stadium with his adopted tape, the drain that sometimes decided to sing. The day after they returned, rain took the city by the shoulders and shook it, and Dara ran in it until her shirt clung in a way that did not deserve poetry, and she let her head be a metronome for her legs, and she felt the old picture try to come in through a corner and she told it, not cruelly, that it could watch if it wanted but it could not comment.

The live stream happened under a tent that wanted to be a set. The producer had assembled a small altar of props that said running without screaming it, and a young host with dimples asked questions like he had rehearsed empathy and passed. People in chat asked about warm-up and about breakfast and about shoes and about prayer and about playlists and one person asked, “Are you really scared or is it just for brand,” and the host made a face that said he wanted to skip it and the producer made a face that said he wanted to measure it, and Dara said, “I’m scared of many things, like everyone. I run anyway.” Someone typed, “Like Spider-Man,” and a dozen laughing faces moved up the screen like bubbles, and Dara glanced at the corner of the tent where a web had drawn a straight line between two plastic poles and found herself smiling because sometimes the city gives you a gift sideways. She did not make a joke she could have made. She let the smile be private. After the stream, a small girl in a faded school shirt came up with a pen that didn’t work and eyes that did, and said, “Mbak, if you are scared why do you do it,” and Dara said, “Because I love it more than I am scared of it,” and the girl nodded as if love were a recipe and her mother said terima kasih in a voice like a blanket.

Rafi had a small fever the day after, the kind that makes a room smaller and numbers less polite. He slept like a person who had assigned someone else his jokes for a night, and their mother counted while pretending not to count and made tea for no reason but the teapot needed to practice, and Dara sat in the chair that had become her shape and read the same sentence four times and did not make herself feel stupid for it. A nurse new to their part of the ward came in with sharp competence and a wrist that wore three hair ties and two bracelets and a watch trying to mind all its hours, and she said the fever would go because the meds would remember what to do and because he was young and young has a way of arguing with heat, and she updated the chart like a drawing. Dara watched a tiny mite that was not a spider stroll along the edge of the bedrail and she did not give it a story; she flicked it away because it was in the wrong place and thought about how it is possible to be gentle and efficient with an enemy.

At practice, Bu Rara returned like a rumor that had decided to become a person and walked them through a simple piece of mind work that felt like a trick until it wasn’t. “We’re going to let a thought be a car on a road,” she said, “and we’re going to watch it drive by without trying to stop it or get in,” and Vina snorted and said hers were motorbikes that do not stay in lanes and Naya said hers were angkot that stop whenever they like, and they all made fun of themselves until their laughter tired, and then they stood in the drizzle and watched their brains make embarrassing choices and refused to be embarrassed. Dara felt an old picture pull up to the curb, a small eight-legged taxi that had been honking outside for years, and she did not get in; she watched it idling and then turn a corner it always turns when ignored. The coach observed from a few meters away with the expression of a man watching modern dance and trying to decide whether it was a joke, and then he said, “Kalau bisa bantu, ya sudah,” and pulled out his stopwatch to do the thing he knows.

A local journalist came with hair like a thesis and asked if the city had been kind to her, and she said the city had been itself and that was nearly always enough, and the journalist asked about Jakarta and the sound there and the way the last ten meters feel and whether the body tells the truth, and Dara said the body sometimes lies to protect you and sometimes lies to hurt you, and your job is to catch it in the act and forgive it anyway. The piece came out the next day with a picture of her that looked like she knew her lines and the headline stole the line about weather because headlines are magpies. Vina teased her for an hour and then sent her a screenshot where a comment said, “My daughter wants to run now,” and it stopped being a game for a second and became a reason.

Weeks spiraled with a discipline the calendar writes when a person has decided on a part of themselves to grow. She kept the counting that had started to feel less like compulsion and more like accompaniment. She kept stepping into shoes without ceremony. She kept saying the word that had once made her skin buzz and now sometimes did nothing but measure a breath. She still jumped sometimes at a dark curl in a corner, but she did not give it all her blood. Rafi’s numbers went up and down like a coastline drawn by someone who had not yet been to geography class, and he pretended to be unfazed more times than he was, and they both refused to let bravery be a law. The sponsor continued to find angles and occasionally found grace. The coach continued to be a rock with a watch and occasionally let a joke happen in front of his own mouth, which meant a lot to the ones who were paying attention. Naya qualified for something small and important and celebrated it by eating noodles with too much chili and calling it strategy. Vina posted a video of her false start that she framed as a metaphor and a warning and a comedy, and the city applauded because the city is good at applause.

The day came when Dara ran a set in practice and did not think about correction or weight or fear for three entire minutes, and it felt like flying because flying is not the absence of gravity but the agreement with it, and she thought, after, sitting on the grass with tape around her finger like a ring, that this could be a life: the lanes, the visits, the small bread things her mother puts in plastic boxes, the sponsor who will eventually find a new story, the coach who will eventually choose a new kid to bark at, the spider she will see one day in a bathroom mirror and not flinch at, the brother who will be in a room that is not this one and will say something that saves her for the afternoon. She thought of the hurdle she hit and the bruise that had bloomed and the word she learned to say without summoning and the rhythm that lives at calf and shin and hinge, and she let herself want the next race without apology.

When the sun decided to go down that evening it did it like a good exit, quickly, a bow and a soft step. The neighborhood filled with the kind of music you don’t plan and the kind of cooking you don’t measure, and she sat on her bed and wrote nothing and read nothing and closed her eyes and saw the ten bars in a row like teeth and did not feel afraid. She messaged Rafi a picture of the dog with the tape and he wrote, “He knows how to run with his fear,” and she wrote, “He knows how to chew it,” and he wrote, “Same,” and even the machine in his room made a sound that could be interpreted as a laugh if you wanted to be generous. She was generous. She lay back. The ceiling stayed stubbornly itself. The night belonged to anyone who could hold it for a second, and for once, and then again, she could.

The first morning after Jakarta that felt like a morning again arrived with a light that had decided to be kind. The hills above Dago sent down a breeze that had learned to speak to sweat politely, and the stadium, smaller than the one that had held her in its mouth last week, looked relieved to be only itself. Pak Bram called hills because sometimes you have to ask the legs to argue with gravity in a different dialect, and they went out the back gate in twos and threes to the steep little road that curled like a question behind the university. The asphalt there was patched with tar that had cooled in shiny kidney shapes, and the angkot brakes barked like small mean dogs as they inched their way down, and the vendors were only just arranging their sopi-sopi, those temporary tables that hold breakfast like it is a fragile porcelain.

She ran the repeats with the efficiency of someone who wanted this to be done and wanted it to do something to her. Hills do not give you glamour, but they carve a kind of nobility into your calves if you let them. Naya matched her for the first four and then fell back with a grin that said she was doing math in a way that would pay her body interest later. Vina turned each ascent into a performance, knees higher, arms theatrical, talking between sets to an imaginary camera because the real one would arrive this afternoon and she liked to keep her dialogue warm. On the last rep, midway up where the slope kicked like a mule with timing, Dara felt her breath clutch and tried not to make a bargain with it. She let the step be just a step. She kept her hips forward. She let the road rise and she met it.

Back at the field, a small tent with a logo had sprouted near the bleachers, the sponsor’s colony marking. A man with shoes that did not trust the ground sipped coffee from a paper cup and looked at them like a farmer appraising a crop. The producer from the warehouse smiled with continuity, as if this morning were still part of that script. She waved at Dara, a wave that said welcome and also said we have chores. They waited until the last of the cool-down jog had sobered the team, and then the producer clapped her hands as if birds might land. “We loved last week,” she said, efficient brightness in each syllable. “The comments were so engaged. The brand feels there is an opportunity to speak to youth about resilience. We’re proposing—” she gestured, and the man in the formal shoes swiped to a new image on his tablet, an athlete mid-air, bars stylized into geometric shapes like art had met athletics and they had agreed to sit near each other.

The next slide was a sketch she did not like. A net, thin and elegant, stretched behind an athlete, and the tagline in English, because English implied sophistication to someone in an office: Run Through What Catches You. A smaller line beneath, in Bahasa, playful: Tembus Takut. The sketch was good, actually, clean lines and the white space used with taste. The problem was the deliciousness with which the idea treated her nerves.

“No nets,” Dara said, not unkindly. She kept her tone like a lane: blunt and marked.

The producer’s brightness didn’t dim, it re-angled. “Of course, we hear you. The concept is metaphorical.”

“Metaphors have bodies,” Dara said. She felt her skin collect, a tightness under the clavicle that she knew how to measure now. “We can talk resilience. Not the web. Not the net.”

The man with the shoes cleared his throat into a smile. “We can revise visuals. Core message is powerful.”

Pak Bram watched the exchange with the expression of a man who had decided to let his runner test her start alone. He lifted one eyebrow in a way that said choose your fights and nodded when she did. Naya stepped closer, a quiet flanking move. “Maybe rhythm,” she said into the gentle space. “Stability. Keep step,” and the producer, who liked a good pivot when it arrived dressed, brightened genuinely.

“Yes! Rhythm. Count. We can do something with meter, heartbeat, your step count,” she said, fingers dancing a new shape in the air. “Less scary. More… method.” She made the word sound like a couture label.

They let the new idea live long enough to grow a sketch right there, the tablet filling with lines and arrows, and the man’s shoe finally trusting the ground enough to scuff a little. The producer glanced at Dara and did a small bow with her head that acknowledged both a battlefield avoided and a path chosen. Bad compromises rot, good ones can feed you.

At the hospital later, the air in the ward had that particular calm that announces the hour when even machines try to lower their voices. Rafi was propped with a magazine he had no intention of reading and a bandage that made his arm look like a prop from a play. The fever had receded as predicted, leaving fatigue like a tide line. He smiled when she walked in with a container of kue lapis, the colors stacked like optimism.

“My athlete,” he said in a voice that had borrowed sandpaper but was still his.

“My patient,” she said, placing the sweets where food would decide their schedule, not them. “They want to wrap me in metaphors.”

“Please tell me you said you would only wear similes,” he said, and then winced because the laugh he wanted would cost him. She sat and told him about the pitch and the net and the pivot to rhythm, and he nodded, pleased like an old coach who approved of a training macrocycle he wouldn’t have designed himself. “There’s music in it,” he said. “People like seeing you count what they can’t.”

She looked at his hand, at the finger where a nail had fallen off and was growing back stubborn and ugly the way healing sometimes is, and she thought about counting that was not steps. “You want garden?” she asked after a beat. He had gotten three days of good numbers in a row. Sometimes you ask for the treat only when you are almost sure you will not be refused.

He wanted garden. The nurse with the three hair ties and the watch that worked hard signed them out like passengers on a short ferry and warned them about wind because wind on a roof is a different animal from wind on a street. The garden had learned them by now; it arranged its light so the bench they liked was not wet, it held the jasmine’s smell back a little because it was new and could be rude, it presented a spider web without its owner strung between a low branch and a railing like lace that had chosen sobriety. Rafi tipped his head to it like to an elder. Dara watched the way the dew had beaded along the threads, each drop with its own idea of gravity. She did not step around it more than she needed. She did not report the sighting to any alarm inside. They sat and talked about what noodles to eat in two weeks if the numbers behaved a bit longer, and they talked about the boy in the next bed who had a voice like a radio and told stories into the night, and they talked about whether the city had more green left in it than people said, and they let the wind be the third voice in their conversation.

Training changed shape the way a song slows when you reach the bridge. The speed remained but the emphasis moved. They worked drills that had the brain listening for rhythm even when breath tried to distract it. Bu Rara had them mark out strides with chalk on the track, faded dots that their feet learned like a child's string game. Dara found that when she was watching for her count she had less space for other pictures and felt a fury at the simplicity that made her say, later, to Naya, “Why didn’t anyone tell me to look at the dots earlier,” and Naya said, “They did, in different ways. You needed it to look like chalk.” Vina mocked the dots until she stumbled her own count and then she fell in love with them in a day and put “dots are my guide” on a story that would make it to someone’s for you page who needed it.

In the locker room one Thursday, there was an actual creature again. This time it wasn’t a jump-scare thrown by fate. It was small, brown, not a myth, near the drain under the bench. The younger girls squealed because they were allowed to and then moved back too far because they thought they weren’t. Dara felt the old elevator drop in her chest, the hitch that used to spoil entire mornings. She stood there, the bag half open, the towel already smelling like a thousand showers, and watched the animal move, quick and certain in its own axis. She heard herself breathe. She did not look for anybody to rescue her from a thing she hated. She took the plastic container that held her hair ties, emptied three elastics into her pocket, and squatted the way her coach hated because he said that posture had a way of making knees into arguments. She slid the container slowly until it was a room over the spider. She felt the thread of disgust hum along her forearms like a warning wire. She held steady, slid the lid with awkward kindness and felt it click. Her heart allowed itself one ridiculous flourish and then retook its seat. The girls watched like she had performed a trick; Vina had been in the doorway and clapped once, impertinent and approving. Dara carried the container outside and tipped it into the grass with a motion that betrayed the tiny tremor she still had, and the spider, unafraid of her as it had always been, decided its own direction and went. She walked back in and forced herself not to pant like a hero.

Later, in the set, her body answered her with a steadiness that felt like interest paid on a long debt. Count, lift, place, cut the air where it wants to hold you. She stumbled once at five because habits do not go to the grave without a fight, and she smiled into the mistake like a person who finally recognizes their mischievous cousin.

The sponsor came back with the rhythm concept solid enough to touch. They had lines cut into vinyl that they laid on the track for a staged shoot after practice on a Sunday when the sky had decided to bless the city with a bright that did not sting. The lines looked like music made into a path, white ticks a cadence. They asked her to run and then to walk and then to stop and talk, the camera close enough that she could count the pores of the lens itself. “Tell us what you hear when you run,” the host asked with those dimples bestowing comfort, and she said the names of small sounds she had never bothered to name before: the whisper of a sock sliding up the back of a heel where the tape ends, the click when spike meets bar by accident, the way breath fills the space inside a mask you pretend isn’t there on polluted days, the way Naya’s laugh sounded like a permission that had finally been granted, the way the coach’s whistle could be a prayer or a curse depending on how it entered your chest. The comments later would call it poetry; to her it was inventory.

At home, her stepfather had tools out on the floor like an altar to metal. He had taken apart a small fan and was cleaning out the dust that had the color of many months piled. He nodded at her, and she nodded back because in their new language nods were paragraphs. “I made something,” he said finally, in a way that suggested he would accept mild mockery as a tax. He led her outside to the small yard crowded with pots that had slid from her mother’s ambition to grow greens to a pragmatic acceptance of what would live; he had welded two old bicycle frames and a length of pipe into a makeshift hurdle, the top bar fashioned from a smooth slat of wood he had planed himself. It was heavier than regulation, and ugly in a way that made it handsome. “For latihan di rumah,” he said, like he had purchased a small satellite and parked it near the potted chili.

She laughed with her whole face and with a soft ache in the throat. “It’s… perfect,” she said, and meant it. He looked relieved in a way she had never seen, as if he had been holding a plank with his teeth and could set it down. He said he had watched a video of her doing drills and had decided he could make a thing she could argue with at home. “You stand here,” he demonstrated badly, knees creaking, and she loved him a little worse for pretending his body had forgotten the flood. He looked at the drain near the back step and then away and then back. “I closed this,” he said, as if anticipating a rebuke that did not come. “Only when hujan besar.” She said okay because it was okay.

The gotong royong spirit, that village muscle city life tries to forget, pulled its weight the following week when storm water laughed at the stadium’s drains. The far corner turned into a mirror, and the frog came back with cousins. The coach threw his hands in the air and then used them to set cones in the gym. They did plyometrics inside where the shouting of boys playing futsal next door made everything feel like a market. Her stepfather appeared at the edge of the field wearing his work shirt and a stubbornness, carrying a snake of coiled hose and a length of rebar like he had made a date with the concept of flow. He and two other men who had been boys here once and then went away and then came back got into the drain with the easy heroism of people who do not ask to be photographed while shoulder-deep in the old city’s secrets. He looked up once at Dara, face shining with rain and effort, and did that nod they had taught themselves. She did the nod back that contained gratitude without a speech.

When the water receded with a sulk, they went back out and ran curved runs on lanes five and six to avoid the silt smear on the inside. Naya made a joke about a new event, 380 meters with mud hazard, and Vina pretended to slip for the camera and then slipped for real and fell on her pride more than her ass and laughed because she would rather be known for laughing than for sulking. Dara felt the familiar urge to scan the edges of the lane and practiced the thing Bu Rara had given them: she allowed the scan and then let it be a car on the road, going by, not stopping. She counted. She let the drumbeat be a drumbeat, not a warning. She let herself run until the part of her that had wanted to be dramatic lay down and took a nap.

National Trials announced themselves in an email that wore a logo and expectation. The field would be deeper, the time standards printed in black like a dare. Jakarta would be hotter, the noise larger, the consequences more expensive. The sponsor sent a careful message asking if they could shoot something in the week before, “pre-race rituals, simple moments,” and the producer promised no props, no nets, no cleverness, just a lens catching hands tying laces and faces deciding. Dara agreed because sometimes saying yes to small things keeps bigger wolves from the door. The brand’s assistant sent a list of questions that included one about fear she left unanswered, and the assistant, a woman who knew how to read silence and did it kindly, did not push.

Rafi had a good week and then a bad afternoon and then a regular day. The hospital had learned to make rollercoasters look like sidewalks. He clowned at a new intern and hit on a volunteer with a nerve that was polite and commented on how her eyeliner was a work of engineering, and then he winced at a pain spiking where sap doesn’t run and swallowed it without being noble. He asked her to bring noodles and then decided the smell made him want to set the world on fire, and she laughed because these were preferences and preferences meant he was not in the part of the story where everything is just endurance. She brought him a small plastic spider from a kid’s toy shop, black and shiny and stupid, and he put it on his IV pole and announced it his mascot, and the nurses groaned and named it Ujang and assigned it a bed number as a joke. He made her take a picture of Ujang supervising his infusion and posted it on a private account with five friends and three cousins, and one of the cousins who used to be a terror wrote, “Respect Ujang,” and it was a silly thing that managed to make the room lighter.

In the one quiet evening before travel, she went to the small mosque at the end of the alley because the call had sounded like a friend. She did not know what to ask beyond the usual and a new thing that had no name. She found she did not need to ask, only to stand and bow and stand again and make her breath obey a pace that had nothing to do with meter marks and everything to do with living through a day. Back home, her mother was already boiling water to fill a thermos for the next morning because mothers prefer to have already taken care of a future before it arrives and disappoints them. The note on the fried rice this time said simply: for after, and had a small heart drawn as if her mother felt embarrassed by art. Her stepfather oiled the hinge of the bedroom door that had squealed for three months because he had finally heard it enough times to decide it had been insulting him personally. They were a house that learned slowly and then forever.

The bus to Jakarta looked the same and did not feel the same. The team had shed the soft weight of hesitation and replaced it with a different restlessness. Naya brought a book of poems and really read it instead of using it as a prop. Vina slept under a hoodie with her mouth open by choice and an earphone in only one ear because attention is a currency she does not completely give to anyone. The coach watched the road with the concentration of a driver and the surrender of cargo. Dara watched the fields and the water that lay between them like sheets a child had left in a yard, and she thought absurdly of spider silk and dew, of the strength of something so small and how angering it is to feel admiration and disgust for the same engineering. She thought of the first time she had counted a full set and the way her heart had thanked her. She put her hand flat to the window again, the old gesture now just a habit without magic, and she said the sentence she had invented for herself, not out loud, not a spell, just a pact: you can ride, you cannot drive.

At the warm-up track, the air smelled like it had been holding its breath since the last big meet and was trying to catch up. The call room did its holy hush act. She went through drills with a calm that surprised her because she had expected to perform her calm and found she had some in stock. The coach said nothing unusual and thus blessed her. The lane number was different this time; the heat draw likes to remind athletes that nothing belongs to them. She pinned the bib with only two stabs to the finger. The volunteer smiled with a kindness that could only have been taught by a grandmother. Everything wanted to be an omen and she let nothing be.

The gun made the sound it makes when you agree to live inside it for a minute. She took the four, took the one, felt three ask for a story and refused, decided early on five to keep the fifteen longer than she had in training because the air had decided not to argue today, and then did the switch where it belonged with less drama than last time. The bar at seven was the bar at seven; she did not make it into her childhood. Eight was where her shoulder knocked with its old rhythm and she held it without scolding. Nine tried to turn itself into a cliff and she made it a curb. Ten was the truth she knew how to tell and she told it. The line took her under its lip and then she was through, and the number told her she had been exact enough to be dangerous to herself.

She won her heat without being the fastest person in the stadium, which is a magic that happens only when you don't demand it. The clock kissed her with a number that would make a coach’s mouth tighten in pleasure. In the final, the day made her run harder than she had run in practice and exactly as hard as she had known she would need to and a hair harder anyway. She did not win the event. The winner had a kick like a lie you want to believe. She came second again, this time with a time that did not apologize for existing. The noise held her as if it had been paid and she had given a good receipt. It was not a miracle; she does not believe in those. It was something else: a day she had earned.

Back at the hotel, her legs ached in coherent sentences. She lay on the carpet and let them talk. Vina spun in the desk chair and filmed them all without warning and posted without malice. Naya applied ice with the malice of a medic and refused to let anyone be dramatic about it. The coach looked like a man who had finally let his shoulders drop in a room where no one would photograph him doing it. The sponsor’s assistant brought fruit plates that had been arranged by someone with a certificate and apologized for the lack of mangosteen as if it were her fault and then took a call from her boss and spoke about “authenticity” without flinching. The producer gave Dara a look from across the room that said thank you for protecting your line. They were all in a life together that did not ask them to declare exactly how much they cared.

On the way back to Bandung, the air over the road had that post-rain gleam that makes everything look like it has been washed and then put back crooked. The bus had a rattle near the door that they had all agreed not to hear. Dara dozed and woke and dozed and woke, and in the second waking she looked up to find that the seat across the aisle held a small actual spider, one leg missing, making a ridiculous journey on the upholstery. It was tiny enough to be forgiven by anyone who was not her, and she watched it and felt the tug and the slide, the old metal in the mouth followed by the new breath that paid it down. She did not panic. She did not call for a killing. She did not name it. She watched it reach the seam, decide, and turn the long way around, sensible for once, and she thought, I am not required to make this a lesson, and she closed her eyes because sleep is a tool she had refused for too long and now she would use it.

When she got to the stadium the next morning—because you go to the stadium after everything, that is the law of this particular religion—the dog was there with his tape, ruined now, just a ribbon, and he had decided it no longer needed parenting and had left it under the bleachers after all that labor. She picked up the tape and tied it to the fence where the breeze could play with it without turning it into trash, and she ran her warm-up in a way that made the past a companion that knew when to shut up. The brain had lied, the body had learned, and both of them, for once, inclined their heads to the day and let it be ordinary, and that, she thought as her foot found its place in the rhythm of a hundred small decisions, was a victory that might outlast medals.

The next week arranged itself into a pattern that looked like a life instead of an accident. Monday belonged to starts and the annoying honesty of film; you think you are lifting, you see on a screen that your hips have opinions. Tuesday went to strength the way a day belongs to a saw: up, down, clean lines if you respect the wood. Wednesday gave them hills again until calves felt carved. Thursday was the day Pak Bram had decided they would clean, which meant he arrived with a broom instead of a speech and told them to be athletes who deserved a place that wasn’t tired of them. The younger boys groaned like he had asked them to donate a kidney; the girls made it into gossip. They dragged a shallow bin along the inside of the bleachers and found the city’s confessions: empty cups, a sock without a sibling, a half-dead fan, a photograph of a face smiling at someone who had removed themselves from the picture. Near the corner where the drain liked to complain, a web held a dust’s version of harvest, grey and polite and empty. Dara looked and did not translate it into a threat. She was bored by her own old habit for a second, and the boredom lightened her limbs like a practical prayer.

Under the third step of the south bleacher, where the stadium stored decades of elbow grease, someone found a cluster of egg sacs, pearls if pearls could also be nightmares. The discovery made the volume of the morning jump; one of the boys lifted his phone and filmed a groan, Vina leaned in then leaned back with the drama she earns, and a cleaner who had been here longer than their coach said calmly that this was every rainy season, with a wide shrug that could hold ten tiny kingdoms and still have space. Dara felt the orchestra in her chest tune up, the old instruments finding notes without being asked. She said the word in her mouth the way she would say “sixteen” before a switch. She took off her training jacket, laid it on the concrete to make a line between the world and her knees, and slid a tray under the step like she had learned to slide lids. The cleaner looked at her with the measured approval older women allot like gold coins. They lifted the step with three hands, slid the sacs into the tray with a paint scraper as gentle as guilt, and carried them to the far end past the fence where the grass was too brave and the lizards made their empires and let the tray be a raft. Someone made a joke about mothers. Someone else made a joke about omens. Dara’s hands shook afterward in that small internal way that leaves no evidence on the surface, and her breathing was ragged, but she was standing, and the ground was just ground. She took the broom again and went back to persuading dust to forgive them for months of stomping.

The sponsor’s tent that had sprouted near the bleachers felt less like a colony that day and more like a neighbor who had brought sugar and gossip. They had asked her to visit a school that sat two streets over and one generation under, and she said yes because the street was their street and she had run past that fence enough times to owe it something. The producer balanced a cake box on her palm and made jokes about bribing attention, and the man who liked his shoes clean tried to adopt a slouch for the alley that did not fit him at all.

The school had the smell that all schools share and no one has managed to bottle: warm paper, ink, resolved arguments, rubber soles, the faint stubbornness of chalk. The badminton court in the yard had surrendered lines to bare feet long ago. They put her on a chair in front and the principal made a speech with three jokes the students had obviously heard before, laughing in the right places like a choir executing a well-practiced harmony. Dara told them about the lane and how it was a friend if you let it be boring, she told them about the hurdle and how it stopped being a wall when you taught your body the steps like a nursery rhyme, and she told them a little about fear without saying fear, because she was not there to make drama a subject. She showed them how to count fifteen with the body. A boy in the third row asked if running made her rich in a tone that contained no malice, only economics. She said running made her tired and then satisfied and sometimes gave her bus tickets; wealth was a thing she would not pretend to explain until someone paid her to do it.

After the questions, when pictures had been taken in groups that made no sense and every phone had captured a version of her eyes looking somewhere else, a small boy tugged her sleeve and said he had something to show her and could he show her outside where it was brighter. He had a jar with holes poked in the lid and a creature inside that had decided it would look best if it did not move. The boy said his name was Ari with the self-importance of a person who had named himself a thousand times in games. He tipped the jar like it contained a treasure and not a trigger. It was a jumper, small, black, with a ridiculous arrogance that only something that size can afford, its front legs held like knives, its body a tight punctuation. The jar smelled like leaves and boy hands.

Dara felt the old elevator drop again and then stop halfway between floors because control had remembered its job. She crouched until she was at Ari’s face, and in the crouch she felt the echo of a coach’s scold and ignored it. She asked Ari if he had caught it in the classroom, because that would have been a story; he said on the fence, and he said it ate mosquitoes and it was his pet until recess ended. He said, with the solemnity of children who’ve read a thing and now own it, that spiders are not insects, and she smiled because pedantry in the right hand can be a balloon. The producer pretended to look away and actually looked because this kind of thing is gold with marketing glaze. Dara looked at the jar and did not look away, not even once, and she felt the buzzing at the back of her mouth settle, not into comfort, but into an argument that did not require shouting. She told Ari that he was not wrong, that the tiny hunter was doing a job inside the world she had not asked to be born into, and then she asked him if he could return it to work. They walked to the hedge by the wall and unscrewed the lid together and tipped the jar and the little animal did not jump onto her, did not attack, did not reenact her story; it went onto the leaf, because the leaf was the right thing. The boy went back to class carrying nothing and feeling bigger. The producer, to her credit, did not dangle the moment in front of a lens. The brand’s assistant handed Ari a sticker like a medal and made no speech. Sometimes people know how to behave.

The day dropped its middle on the ward with the abruptness it reserves for hospitals. Rafi had woken with a number that took the floor out of their mother’s knees, and he had spent the morning wearing a stubborn heat that blushed his cheeks like a slap. The nurses flowed around him with competence that could calm a train, and the doctor used a voice he saves for days when he cannot fix anything immediately but can still fix his tone. Sepsis is an ugly word that pretends to be Latin for drama. It is just a door you do not want to walk through. They flooded him through a line that had learned his vein’s name by now, and their mother counted the drops without looking like she was doing arithmetic, and the ward hushed the way wards hush when there is emergency but not panic. Dara sat on the chair that had accepted her shape and texted the coach that she would not be at the second session, not later and not in an hour and not if she ran from here to the track in slippers. She did not add apology. She did not add explanation beyond the obvious. You have to let people fill in their own blanks sometimes.

He replied with a thumb that could be read three ways and a sentence that had the humility he uses like a muscle. He said to stay where she was; he said they would run again tomorrow; he said the wind would still be there. She put the phone away because the room needed fewer screens. Rafi burned and then wavered and then came back down as if recovery were a polite descent. He coughed once and apologized for the volume like a man pulling his weight at his own funeral and she smacked his arm lightly because he didn’t get to joke about that part. In the late afternoon, when the ward had decided it could do regular life again, the coach appeared at the door with that expression he gives when he has something in his hand that embarrasses him. It was a bottle of isotonic drink and a bag of sliced fruit that had been wrapped in plastic so tight it looked like it had been vacuum-sealed for space. He placed it on the bedside cabinet as if crossing a finish line and looked everywhere except at Rafi’s tubes. He told Rafi to get better like it was a drill and told him his sister was irritating when she didn’t have anyone to outrun. Rafi thanked him like a man being introduced to a neighbor’s dog for the second time.

An hour later, in the corridor, the coach confessed, in the dry way he has when a sentence costs him what he thinks is pride and is actually just an old habit, that he had once watched a teammate have a seizure on the infield, the way a body insists on its own electricity and everyone else looks at the sky because they want to ask for a refund. “Since then,” he said, scratching the back of his neck with a thumb as if the words had come out the wrong door, “I don’t like any of you doing drama on the ground. Keep it standing. If fall, fall in line. You understand.” He looked like he had admitted to owning a small, foolish pet that he also loved. She said she understood without making it bigger than it was. Behind him, down the corridor, her stepfather appeared with a plastic bag that had been bought to replace the previous plastic bag and held the same food because routine is medicine you can afford. The two men nodded to each other with that wary respect men reserve for one another when they cannot measure who is more necessary to the girl between them. The coach left with his watch set to comfort. Her stepfather took his place in the chair and made a joke about Ujang, the mascot spider, asking for visitation rights.

The call about camp arrived while she and Naya were tying the elastic bands that make a person’s hips honest. National training would be held at Ragunan for six weeks. There would be two coaches who had not learned their names yet, a physio who would, and an official who would count everything and then count it again as if this time numbers might decide to be kinder. The group chat lit with blistering optimism, then settled into logistics like a cooking show: who would water the plant in Vina’s room that she insists is a basil and is actually a pothos, who could feed the lanky cat that lived behind the long jump sand and had had kittens on their day off, who could be trusted to tell the sponsor that no, they would not do a live from weights. Dara read the message twice and kept her face smooth. Rafi stuck a thumb up from his pillow that carried a cannula. He said go before she asked. He said if she did not, he would make her tie him to his IV pole and drag him to training, which would be embarrassing for everyone because he would be the slowest thing on the track. She did a bad bow from the waist while sitting and he laughed with his eyes and then with his chest when it stopped hurting.

That night, at home, her mother folded clothes that had nothing to do with training with a care that would put a laundry detergent advertisement to shame. She put socks together that had long ago chosen to divorce and, through sheer maternal stubbornness, forced a reconciliation. She wrote a note on a piece of paper that had been used for a list of prices on one side and a prayer on the other and tucked it into the side of the bag where the tape lives. Dara would not see the note until the fourth day in camp, when she would need it. Her stepfather stood in the door with his arms crossed because he had nothing to do with packing except wanting and not knowing where to put it. He said he’d go to the hospital on Wednesdays and Saturdays when she couldn’t, and he said it in a voice that pretended it was a suggestion and wasn’t. She said thank you and meant it in a way that wrapped old and new recognition around his name. Later, he tested the hinge he had oiled and smiled at it as if it had thanked him.

The national dorms had beds that pretended to be stern and rooms that smelled like fifteen years of dreams and anti-mold packets. The communal bathrooms had tiles that had been chosen by someone who resented color. Her roommate was a hurdler from Manado named Lia who wore her hair in a bun that made her look like she never left business to accident. Lia had a way of speaking that made bad news sound like an invitation to dance and good news sound like an assignment. On the first night, Lia took her to the bathroom on their floor like she was introducing a new friend to an old friend and said if the water is cold, hit it, and if the light flickers, talk to it. On the second morning, around five, the flicker was the least of it. There was a spider the size of an old coin on the shower wall, tuley brown, slow, deliberate, obviously not interested in girls with soap. Lia said “hai” to it like you say to an aunt you haven’t decided to love yet. Dara felt the usual involuntary poem start in her chest and then interrupt itself. She took the plastic bowl they used to pour water on their heads and pressed it to the tile with a care that surprised her and slid it down until bowl met floor. “You okay?” Lia asked, half ready with a giggle, half with genuine care. Dara breathed two times and took the flat, cheap sandal she hated and slid it under the bowl as a lid, then took the whole construction outside to the corridor and tipped. The spider made a decision and took the corner toward the stairs. Lia made a sound that was ninety percent delight and ten percent “ew.” Later, in the dining hall, she told three girls at breakfast that her roommate was ridiculous and brave and Dara did not correct the order.

The camp introduced her to Sari with the formal informality of athletes who have already met across lanes. Sari had been the woman from Semarang leaning into the finish like a thesis. Up close, she was someone you would trust to hold your wallet and beat you to the last seat on the bus; these things, in a good person, coexist. They ran side by side as if the track had been waiting for the two of them to pack each other’s lunches. They sorted out their rivalry without words, in the way strides stretch, in the way breaths match and then diverge. Sari asked in the gym if it was true about fear and a sponsor and a net, and Dara rolled her eyes and said a brand tried to embroider her nerves and she had told them to bring thread for her calves instead. Sari grinned like approval is a sport. They shared a physio who had hands like a clockmaker and a habit of humming 90s love songs while scraping out the nonsense that lives in a hamstring. They avoided the national official who had decided it was his job to teach them how to smile like medals. They learned the cafeteria’s bad days and the good seat where the AC did not aim at the back of your neck like a gossip.

On the third week, her phone vibrated with a message from her mother that held only the word “bisa” and then a list of times. She called the ward from under a shade tree that was trying to decide whether it was a therapeutic presence or a shelter for smokers. The doctor said “eligible” like a word had been allowed to put its shoes on. A donor match had been found for Rafi, not perfect, but a near enough sister to the blood that the body might be persuaded to accept it; there would be a window, logistics were commotion, the hospital would be a choreography of white coats and moving parts and permissions. Transplant was a word Dara had previously met only in late-night articles and other families’ stories; now it stood in her living room.

She walked the perimeter of the little field behind the dorm where damp collects and small frogs try their luck. She counted for no reason except to remind herself that numbers could be domesticated; one breath, two, three, like chalk dots underfoot without the chalk. She told herself to stay until there was a reason to go. She called the coach, her coach, not the national one who barely knew her name and liked to say “you people” as if that were efficient, and she told him the news, half expecting the sound of a whistle inside his throat. He said “good” like he meant it, then he said “gulp the training,” and she understood he meant do not break your shape with worry. He said if a day arrives that needs you, the track will wait. She cried in a way that would be invisible to anyone who was not holding her face at the time. Then she wiped it with the back of her hand like a kid who has had practice.

There was a day when a rumor tried to take the lane. Someone online, with a username that sounded like a name and a face that refused to be a face, wrote that fear was a marketing tool and that she had made spiders into a product to sell shoes. It would have made her eyes hot a month ago. As it was, she threw her phone toward the bed and missed and retrieved it and then sent the link to Vina with the note “Come collect your people.” Vina screenshotted the ridiculousness and posted it with a caption that made a joke out of how little content creators needed to eat, and then she called, which surprised Dara because this is not usually what Vina does. She said, in a voice that had put its lipstick away, that people on the internet are a fog and you do not make turns based on fog. She said also, awkward like a shoe on the wrong foot, that she had been jealous of the attention and had said one and a half mean things that were hers and not the fog’s, and she apologized by calling herself a clown twice, which was her version of kneeling. Dara accepted, heartily, and then made fun of her for not knowing what pothos is. They were silly on the phone for long enough that the rumor was forced to look for a new shape to sit in.

The national coach, a man with a jaw like a stapler, ran them on the grass in diagonals and made them run again when the diagonals were not straight enough for his eyes. He used words like “movement quality” and “inhibition,” and when someone groaned, he said he would inhibit their breakfast. They learned, in the way girls who run learn quicker than anyone thinks, that half of this game is keeping your head where you told it to be. In the dorm that night, Lia told Dara that there had been a tarantula in her aunt’s house in Bitung as big as a hand and that her aunt had called it swear words and left it alone and it had left, and that bravery sometimes looks like not cleaning. Dara said she could get behind that definition. She went to brush her teeth and the bathroom was empty of drama and the mirror did not have any messages for her. She regarded her face with the curiosity of a stranger who might buy.

On the fourth day of the fourth week, the hospital asked for signatures on papers that had corners and read like small constitutions. Their mother wore her neatest clothes that were not neat and her neatest breath that was not steady, and their stepfather signed his name like someone who had taught his hand late and it still wanted to forget its letters. Rafi, who had shed much of his vanity with his hair, insisted that Ujang attend the consent conference taped to the side of the IV pole like a witness. Dara listened on video and said yes to the Yes parts and breathed through the parts that sounded like materials written to cover every hypothesis. The nurse with the three hair ties and the bracelets nodded at her through pixels like a friend telling you they would keep a seat for you at the stupid party in case you arrived late.

The night before the procedure, she sat with Naya on the low curb behind the track and they ate noodles from a packet that all runners pretend they do not eat and then confess to loving. They talked about lanes because that was safe, and then they talked about Rafi because life had asked, and Naya told a story about an aunt’s operation that turned out to be less dramatic than the story had promised and how sometimes the world uses the language of catastrophe to describe a day that ends in a sandwich. Dara held the thought like a warm coin. The national coach passed them in the corridor later and said “lights out” as if he could enforce the night, and they said “yes, sir” with the practiced insolence of girls who would sleeplessly count anyway.

In the morning, she ran before the sun committed, because the body knows how to pray in its own dialect. The warm-up track had a cat who had decided that the coil of a hose was its kingdom; she didn’t disturb the monarchy. She did A-skips and B-skips and small hops that told her ankles the truth, and she counted fifteen with breath, not with steps, and she remembered to keep her arms quiet because noise radiates. She finished with two accelerations that made the air part in front of her as if it had a plan for her shape. Then she went back, showered, put on real clothes because hospitals notice when you arrive looking like you live there, and took the bus to the ward because she did not trust her legs not to take her to the track if she went on foot.

The ward had organized itself into a quiet that was not fake. The donor’s blood, persuaded by a government database and good luck, had arrived cold and correct. Rafi joked twice without catching breath and had to stop, and then he did the serious thing people do before anesthesia by making insane faces, and then he went in. Their mother sat as if the chair was a talking thing and she was trying to hear the words. Their stepfather, who had never called any man “doctor” in his life without feeling cheated, called four men in coats “Doctor” and meant it. Dara walked the corridor and did not think about corners. She texted the coach that she would be out of the group chat noise. He replied with an emoji that could be a fist or a potato depending on your generation. Hours do the strangest stretches in hospitals. You already know this if you’ve ever watched lamplight change on tile and tried not to count because counting makes it worse.

It went. Of course it went; she would not tell this story like this from the other side if it did not. It was not miracle, again. It was science with a handshake from mercy. The doctor said what doctors say when things have done what they are supposed to do without making a scene: now we wait, now we watch, now we do not insult the body with too much celebration at the wrong time. When they rolled him out and parked him in his new reality, he looked like sleep held his weight for him. Their mother cried the kind of tears that clean you out and leave you stable; not salt, but water. The nurse with the bracelets winked at Dara like an accomplice and said “good” in a tone that had known every version of “bad.” Ujang, foolishly taped to the pole, looked down on the proceedings with the comfort of a mascot whose work here was done and would begin again tomorrow.

She went to sleep that night back at the dorm as if she had earned the right to be unconscious. In the morning, the body insisted on its routine like a friend being gentle. Sari met her at the track and did not ask for news but kept pace easy and matched her breath so they could keep a conversation without adding words. Vina sent a video of herself saying something stupid to a camera about breakfast, and Dara laughed, and it wasn’t a rebellion or a statement, it was a release valve. The national coach did not praise more because he did not know how; he barked less. Bu Rara sent a voice note that said nothing useful and somehow helped, a calm voice reminding her to count stones on a path instead of looking into bushes. Her stepfather messaged a photograph of the homemade hurdle with rain beads on it like small medals, and her mother sent a picture of a bowl of soup and wrote “for after” because she wasn’t going to retire a good note for one time.

The Trials were set to begin the week after the first markers of Rafi’s acceptance would appear in numbers that had learned her name. The stadium in Jakarta would look no different to a new runner and entirely different to a girl who had carried a jar with a web once. She stood in the lane during the last practice before travel and watched the lines as if they might back away, then looked up because she had learned that sometimes the sky is as busy as the ground. A bird that had made the track its commute dropped a very small feather onto lane five, and it drifted with a carelessness she envied and then landed near the takeoff for three, and she did not make it significant. She counted. She ran. Then she ran again, and this time when the old tug under her shoulder arrived, she let it ride without paying it with a grimace it did not deserve. Naya shouted something unhelpful and loving. The coach’s whistle cut a line in the morning and then softened. The city, that old person who watched from beyond the wall, said nothing because it did not need to. She had enough voices in her chest now that made sense.

That evening, she packed with the efficiency of a person who had repeated a life until it obeyed. She placed the tape where it belongs, the sachet in the pocket her hand knows even in the dark, the spikes wrapped in a shirt that did not deserve to smell like them. She took the note her mother had tucked and finally read it: a list of small instructions that had nothing to do with running and everything to do with being a person: drink water but not too much before gun; call after; if you see a cat, do not kick it; if you see a big person, remember they were small once; if you see a small thing that scares you, remember it does not know you. She laughed and cried and then did neither. She turned off the light and lay in the dark and did not make it a metaphor. The morning would arrive with its own feet. She would meet it where she always did: lane, line, count, breath, a body that had learned, a brain that had decided to be less creative, a family that coursed through her in as invisible a way as blood, a fear that had gotten bored with being the main character and learned to play a supporting role. She slept, and her sleep made no promises beyond the polite ones. The city filled the rest.

The week folded itself around departures as if travel were a person who had to be accommodated. In the dorm, Lia narrated the packing like a sportscaster because it calmed her nerves and entertained whoever walked by their door: tape in first because ankles have seniority, spikes wrapped in the shirt you hate because they will punish it with their smell, toiletries in a pouch that pretends order is possible for small bottles, the lucky hair tie even if you don’t believe in luck. Dara let herself move slower than the clock demanded, not as a rebellion but because slowness is its own strategy when the head wants to sprint ahead and check every corner for a trap. Her phone lay face down on the bed like a guest who had fallen asleep on the sofa, and when she flipped it, the messages were a small street fair: the sponsor’s assistant reminding her of a polite appearance after heats, the coach’s “ingat makan,” her mother’s three shades of prayer disguised as instructions to wear socks at night so her calves wouldn’t “masuk angin,” and a video from the ward where Ujang had been ceremonially retired from the IV pole with a tiny paper “terima kasih” sign taped beside him. The nurse with the bracelets said, off-camera and with a wink that translated across pixels, that mascots need rest too, and Rafi, in a voice that had borrowed steadiness again, declared that Ujang had been promoted to head of risk management and would now live on top of the TV where dust goes to die.

The bus down to Jakarta carried the same smells and complaints and astonishments it always did, the rhythm of a body of people trying to arrange themselves into comfort on upholstery never designed for it. Sari sat across the aisle with her knees pulled up and her eyes closed, mouth pulled into a line that could be focus or fatigue, and Naya leaned into the window’s light and turned a poem book face down on her lap like the page needed to breathe. Vina filmed the back of everyone’s head and provided commentary in a whisper that resisted its own impulse to be loud, catching the coach at one point tilting his cap down over his eyes in a gesture that could be interpreted as a nap or a treaty. The road unfurled in its usual patchwork of crops and concrete, and in a field just before Karawang a thin row of banana plants stood like a sketch, their leaves torn by wind into long fingers that had given up pretending to be whole, and Dara let herself look without composing a defense, the image entering and departing like a busker’s song you enjoy without tipping because you have to conserve coins for later.

Ragunan felt different when you arrived with the knowledge of leaving soon. The dorm’s corridor offered the same smell of disinfectant and ambition, but it was less heavy, like an unresolved chord that would resolve within days. The national coach watched them arrival-jog around the grass with his arms crossed and his jaw doing its usual impression of a tool, and his assistant—a woman younger than all their knees—took attendance the way a cashier counts exact change, head down, eyes counting more than names. They loosened with drills that made a person feel ridiculous until the ridiculousness worked, knees up like a puppet, hips forward like a show-off, arms disciplined like a child in a fancy restaurant. Bu Rara found them where shadows gathered in a neat line and asked for five minutes without the stopwatches, which made the national coach perform indignation and then shrug because even he knew he wasn’t the only god here. She gave them a little script: pick three things you will notice in the call room that have nothing to do with you, pick one thing on the track that will anchor you if your head starts becoming a liar, pick one sentence you will say to yourself only once. Dara wrote on her own mind with the new chalk: scuff marks in chair three, the pattern on a volunteer’s lanyard, the number of knots in the mesh over the window, the way the eight takeoff marks look when you walk in lane five, the sentence that was not lyrical and had the decency to be plain—keep hips, count, breathe.

At the hospital, the news had learned how to walk instead of run. The doctor made a shape with his hands that looked like a cup half full of water and said numbers in a tone that had been trained to translate caution into optimism without breaking either. Engraftment had begun like a neighbor knocking lightly at the door then deciding to let themselves in after all. Their mother slept in half-hour pieces and cried in bathrooms only she allowed to know that, and their stepfather patrolled the perimeter of the ward like a security guard who would gladly be demoted if someone else would take the shift; when the nurse scolded him for touching a button he was not supposed to touch, he grinned his apology in a way that announced that he would do it again if he believed the machine was asking for help. Rafi texted “go run” with a frog emoji and a lightning bolt and then added “don’t think, only do,” which made Dara type a paragraph about the impossibility of thinking not thinking and then delete it because he was trying to give her a button she could push that wouldn’t set off an alarm.

The call room on the first day of heats held the same hush that always made her grin internally, because hush in sports is never real, it is only vacationing noise. The volunteer with the lanyard had chosen a pattern of tiny foxes, and Dara counted them in her head for a few seconds and let it mean nothing. The chair three scuff mark had a particular crescent bite out of it, and she decided some sprinter had been nervous enough to dig heel into plastic and had then made a time he would remember for the rest of his useful mind because people like that deserve happy endings in your imagination if you are going to borrow their mark. Sari sat two chairs away and rolled her shoulders with the fatalism of a person opening a door to a room she had renovated herself. A woman from Balikpapan, compact and coiled, blew air out of her cheeks with a soft “puh” that did the work of a joke without stealing any breath. When they were called, the numbers fell into mouthes and lived there briefly, then turned to lanes where they belonged.

The gun snapped the moment into obedience and then trusted the bodies to keep it there. Dara took the four like a sentence she had rehearsed enough to not hate, kept fifteen as if it were a liturgy, let the wall of air at two stop being a wall because she had told it so, and saw at three the old theatre curtain of shadow and refused to let it be the beginning of a play. Her hips stayed where coach and Bu Rara and gravity and her own stubbornness had agreed they should be, and her arms were as uninteresting as a chair leg, which in hurdle running is a compliment. She felt the small giving way at six that had become a friend she let walk beside her rather than behind or in front, and she used the switch like a tool, not a scandal, moving to sixteen with the economy of a person who does not announce she is leaving a party. Nine, which is where liars come to test your temper, offered its usual deal, and she refused it without drama. Ten was the same teeth as before; she bit back and leaned without begging the tape to love her. The clock gave her a time that did not cause arguments and did not require apologies. Sari across the way looked at her with the fast smile of a runner who had read the same paragraph and enjoyed it, and the Balikpapan woman exhaled her “puh” again and added a “syukur” in that small, private way athletes smuggle prayers into secular minutes.

After, the sponsor’s assistant found her like a bee that had decided to be kind and asked for two sentences at the tent with the logo. The producer had set up a simple frame, thank her better angels, just a bench and the lines on the track behind, the rhythm concept manifesting as a visual heartbeat. The young host asked what she had noticed in the call room and, for once, she told the truth in a way that did not feel extracted: the foxes on the lanyard, the scuff on the chair, the way someone’s nail polish had chipped into a map of an island she didn’t recognize and loved anyway, the way the hush sounded like fabric being folded. He asked if she had been afraid and she said she had been more interested than afraid, and that line fell out of her mouth like something she had earned the right to say, and she saw, in the producer’s tiny nod, the relief of someone who had been looking for a way to sell integrity without renting trauma. When they were done, she refused a branded energy bar with polite firmness and took instead an unbranded banana from the bowl, which made the assistant grin like a co-conspirator.

The final the day after decided to be petty about weather. The heat rose up from the track in a visible shimmy that threatened to give seconds away to anyone too stubborn to pay it respect. At warm-up, sweat slicked the line at the back of her knee where the joint speaks, and she adjusted tape by feel because the glue on skin behaves differently when the day has taken sides. Bu Rara found her with a hand on the shoulder from behind, a touch that contained history without needing to announce it, and asked, almost offhand, what her one sentence was today. “Keep hips, count, breathe,” Dara said, then added, because bodies love specificity, “no heroics at seven.” The national coach clicked his tongue in a rhythm that, to his credit, lined up with the metronome they were trying to live inside. Sari tightened her spikes as if she were screwing them into the day.

On the set, a small child in the stands screamed a name that sounded like theirs but might have been someone the child had invented. Dara set blocks with care, the fast ritual of fingers on metal, heel against pedal, palms on surface, mind trimmed to the line. The gun did not betray anyone with an uneven crack. She went out controlled, resisted the bright insult of the backstretch sun, counted the world into a comprehensible list, and then at four something small and quick—paper? leaf? the ghost of a cloud?—caught the corner of her eye, and her brain yanked at the old alarm like a lever you know is supposed to stop trains. She did not lift her head. She did not look for proof or confirmation. She fell into the drum that she now kept as a room inside her chest: laba-laba is a syllable with no assignment, a percussive, a nothing that keeps a beat, count, count, count. The bar came, it always comes; she moved over it with an economy that would not make a highlight reel but would make a coach sigh later in private with satisfaction. The switch later than expected felt like a choice she had already rehearsed in heat, the sixteen arriving like a friend who knew where the spare key was. By eight, the soldiers in her legs had begun to mutter, and by nine they had filed a formal complaint, and by ten everyone had agreed that this was exactly what they had trained to be able to hate. She finished with a time that made the stadium behave, not go wild, but respect, and she stood very still for a second because stillness is sometimes the loudest celebration a body can manage.

She did not win; Sari did, with a finish that had made everyone in the first row lean forward involuntarily, their bodies recognizing expertise. Dara came second, and it was a clean second, not a grudging one. When the board confirmed it with the impersonal kindness of capital letters, she let herself nod once, a movement so small it needed its own microscope, and then walked off because walking uses a different grammar from victory and she wanted to speak both. In the mix zone, someone stuck a phone toward her with the question about brand and resilience already cued, and she answered with a sentence that was part script and part truth, a compromise she was learning to execute without feeling soiled: people see what they can use; I run for what I can hold. The assistant caught her eye over the top of the phone and mimed a tiny bow and then steered the conversation toward shoes, which cost no one anything but money.

In the stands, her mother had come in a bus later than any mother would accept and sat in the second row because an aunt’s cousin’s son worked at the gate and had given her a wristband with more power than it deserved. She clutched a hand fan that had been a wedding souvenir from 2006 and waved it with a ferocity that could have moved weather if weather were polite. Her stepfather sat with knees wide, a man who had learned to take up space late and still wasn’t entirely convinced of his right to do it, and he watched with the attention he gave to engines, listening for a misfire or a tick, relaxing when none came. When she jogged the courtesy circle and saw them, she did not alter her line because she had decided that was a kind of extra she didn’t owe anyone, but she allowed her mouth to tilt in a way that would be visible only if you knew her face. Later, when they met in the concourse where air tries to remember breezes, her mother kissed her forehead with the awkwardness of everyone’s eyes, and her stepfather shook the coach’s hand like men do when a shared project has decided to behave and then ruined the moment by blurting out, “Saya bikin halang rintang di rumah,” with pride, and the coach, who understands artisan craziness when he sees it, said, “Ya bagus, tapi jangan sampai anaknya jatuh di dapur,” and they all laughed, relief making the sound bigger than the joke deserved.

The call from the ward came when she was sitting on her bag trying to trick it into closing without compromising on snacks. It was short and clean. Numbers were good. The doctor had allowed himself the smallest smile on the mask, a movement you could almost miss if you did not know his face already. The nurse with the bracelets said the word engraftment with the same tone she uses to announce afternoon tea. Rafi himself, groggy and proud, said his white blood cells had finally stopped acting like old men in an argument and had allowed the new ones to join the club, and then he coughed and handed the phone to their mother who cried without apologizing for once. Dara told them about the race and did not make her own news into a smaller thing for humility’s sake because she had learned that everyone in this family was allowed to have a headline sometimes.

The national selection meeting was an exercise in bureaucracy disguised as sport, and she sat through it with the patience of a person who has watched drips and beeps become a day. Names were read into rosters and pruned from them; someone’s face fell in a way that made her look away because you don’t ogle another person’s falling. Her name came where she had hoped, not because she believed herself entitled to it but because the work had been done and the work had been the right kind. Sari sat back with that careful breath of someone who will not show relief where it can be counted against her, and they shook hands in a tight, feminine handshake that would look like nothing to anyone who didn’t know these hands had both been educated by wood and rubber and scolding and failure and had learned how to carry a little joy without letting it slip. Vina got her relay spot and made the air taste like sugar for five minutes before deciding she had to post immediately to keep the sweetness from souring without her management. Naya’s name was on a list that had once felt too pointy for her, and she let herself hold her face with both hands for a second and then went to call someone she needed to tell first.

Back home, the sofa in the living room, that old argument turned furniture, received her with its cracked leather and its rude memory. The note her mother had tucked in the tape pocket had been found two days ago when she needed to fix a blister, and she had read it in the bathroom, sitting on the closed lid of the toilet with the old tile’s flowers making their dated parade under her feet. She had folded the paper and put it in the back of her phone case because technology should carry these things when bodies run out of pockets. Her stepfather took her to the yard and pointed at the hurdle like a person introducing a child to a teacher, and she did two drills on it in her slippers because ceremony can sometimes cement love. He told her the drain hadn’t complained in two storms, and she told him that drains and hamstrings are alike: they require maintenance and the acceptance that sometimes they will be stupid for no reason. He laughed and said he preferred engines because engines don’t have histories, and she said engines lie, and he said everything lies if you listen to it wrong, and they both shrugged the way people do when they have found a disagreement that can live safely in the house.

The sponsor, encouraged by the clean narrative arcs of the week, sent a message asking if she would consider a long-form piece about “overcoming,” and she replied with a sentence that had taken her months to learn: she did not overcome anything; she negotiated with it. The assistant sent back three heart emojis that felt sincere and a promise to educate. The producer sent a voice note saying she would bring only one camera if they did a porch interview and would leave if the dog started complaining about the tape again, and Dara said fine because you have to feed some machines to keep their teeth off more important things. She declined a request to film at the hospital and was surprised and warmed when the assistant wrote, “Of course,” and offered alternative images that did not require anyone to tell her brother’s story for him.

One evening, when the light over the alley had decided to be theatrical, she walked to the warung at the end of the street to buy shallots and a packet of coffee her mother swore tasted better because it was cheap. A web had been strung between the two iron bars of a gate in a diagonal that would have offended any geometry teacher and delighted any child. The spider that had decided this was a good place to be was small and brown and unassuming, the project modest and efficient. A boy chased a ball nearby and did the clumsy feint children practice on impervious opponents, and he ran toward the gate, toward the web, toward the inevitable, and she could have shouted, and she did not, because you are allowed to let the world break its minor beauties and remake them tomorrow. The ball hit the post and the web shivered, then held, then gave a little, and the spider moved with the competence of its kind to adjust tension. The boy ran on. The day did not break. She bought shallots and coffee, and the seller threw in two chilies and a “buat cantik” which had nothing to do with looks and everything to do with the way the aunties like to bless the girls who run past their shops and then run into television and then run back again.

At practice the next morning, the dog had finally abandoned the tape and had fallen in love with a cone. He herded it up and down the grass with an attention that would have made him a good assistant coach if he had owned a whistle. The sky over the stadium had acquired the color that makes even the laziest person consider sweeping. Pak Bram had them do a series that started simple and then made small, intelligent demands, and he grunted approval or dismissed slop with equal economy. Bu Rara stood with a notebook she may or may not write in and watched like someone who intends to steal a method and return it improved. Sari texted a picture of her breakfast with a caption that made fun of the coffee at the training center, and Dara sent back a photograph of the homemade hurdle with a filter that made it look more noble than it was. The sponsor’s assistant posted a story of a chalk line and a count, tagged no brands, and wrote only “latih,” which made three teenagers in a school two streets over decide to go for a run that afternoon and argue later whether fifteen was a mystic number or just practical.

In the quiet before the next travel, with the track holding the day’s heat like a memory and the city deciding how to spend its evening, Dara sat on the bleacher and thought about how much of this was accidental and how much was a plan she hadn’t admitted to having. She would go again to the stadium with the bigger mouth and the lights that turn skin into armour or into water depending on the angle. She would visit the ward and take the role the chair had for her and not be heroic about it. She would say no to nets and yes to rhythm. She would put her hand in her shoe without speaking to God first. She would ask her stepfather to check the screws on the homemade hurdle because it had begun to squeak in a way that sounded like a rumor. She would run because she loved it more than she was scared of it, and some days that ratio would reverse and she would pay interest later. She would listen to the body’s lies and the brain’s lies and the day’s lies and choose the version that allowed her to place a foot where it needed to be, on a line painted by someone she did not know, at a speed that made sense only to people whose hearts had decided that the best work is the work you carry inside your chest and never put down. She stood, counted to a number that was both an incantation and a joke, and went to stretch with the ridiculous elegance of a girl who had learned to move inside her own weather without making it the headline.
